Saddle Lake, Alberta,
Twenty-second June 1943

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I enclose application for Admission of Simon Patrick to the Blue Quill's School. The application appears to be in order and I would recommend acceptance as a grant paying pupil. The child is already in school.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
June 30, 1943.

Mr. W.P.B. Pugh, Indian Agent, Saddle Lake, Alta.

With reference to your letter of the 22nd instant, you may inform the Principal of the Blue Quills Residential School that the admission of Simon Patrick Large is approved.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

FORM 611
Ottawa, September 27, 1943.

Mr. W. P. B. Pugh, Indian Agent, Saddle Lake, Alberta,

With reference to your letter of the 10th instant, the Department approves the transfer of Joyce Cardinal No. 0558 from the Blue Quills Indian Residential School to the Youville Indian Residential School.

Please inform both Principals accordingly.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, Canada

Sept. 2, St. Paul, 1984

Sir,

I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child: Thomas Donald Cardinal
English name: Thomas Donald Cardinal
Age: 11
Name of Band: Beaver Lake
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid: #95
Father's full name and No.: Albert Cardinal #95
Mother's full name and No.: Catherine Cardinal #95
Parents living or dead: Living
State of child's health: Good
Religion: R.C.
Does applicant speak English? Yes
Previously attended: No school for years

(Signature of father)

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

Signature of Missionary or other Witness

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

NOTE—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

October 5th 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re Blue Quill's Indian School.

Herewith enclosed quarterly Return for the quarter ending September 30th 1943, together with Admission & Discharge Return of Pupils.

The Principal is asking for the discharge of the following pupils:

242 John Noel, Cold Lake, need at home.
250 Norbert Gibault, Long Lake, need at home.
268 Isidore Janvier, Cold Lake, 16 years old.
266 George McFeeters, Cold Lake, needed at home.
269 Ralph Cardinal, Saddle Lake, need at home.
272 Elsie Minoose, Cold Lake, needed at home.
285 George Youngchief, Long Lake, needed at home.
331 W. Raymond Cardinal, Saddle Lake, fruant.

0222 Melaine Blackman, Cold Lake, needed at home.
0277 Sohastique Janvier, Cold Lake, sick at home.
0289 Agnes Matchawee, Cold Lake, needed at home.
0309 Adelaid Amable, Cold Lake, needed at home.
0344 Caroline Cardinal, Beaver Lake, sick at home.
0267 Mary Jane Whiskeyjack, 16 years old. (Saddle Lake).
0268 Alice Cardinal, Saddle Lake, 16 years old.

The Principal informs me that he discussed the Onion Lake Agency discharges with Indian Agent Cameron and that they are in order. I beg to recommend the Saddle Lake discharges.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

FORM 411
Ottawa, October 19, 1943.

Mr. D. H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Sask.

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of October 5, in which you intimate that Mary Bedger, pupil No. 0595, enrolled at the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, is anxious to be transferred to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, St. Paul, Alberta. It is noted that the St. Paul School is near to the home of this pupil.

In view of this fact, the Department is prepared to authorize the transfer of this pupil and you may notify the principals of the above-mentioned schools to this effect.

P. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, October 19, 1943.

Mr. W. P. B. Pugh, Indian Agent, Saddle Lake, Alberta.

With reference to the September quarter return of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, the Department approves the admission of:

REPORT ON SADDLE LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF SEPTEMBER, 1943.

Schools;
The return of the children too school was terrible as I expected however considerable progress has been made since and the return will be better than last year. No new recruiting been done to date owing to the absence of the Indians, however, if the roads keep fit, I am making plans for a recruiting campaign.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am in receipt of a letter from Reverend Father Latour, principal of the Blue Quill School, in which he states that he would like the Department to authorize the admission of Tobie Badger, Ida John, and Marie-Josephine Gladu of the Keeheewin Reserve.

These children attend at times the Long Lake day-school, but the parents are not satisfied with the training they are receiving there, and wish them to be transferred to a residential school, because they will be able to follow a course in manual training which will fit them much better for the future than the mere elements of the three "P's" which they are now receiving in the day-school which they are supposed to attend. I wish to add that Father Latour states that the parents of these children applied in person to him to have their children admitted in the Blue Quill School, and that it was on the occasion of their visit to the above school that they expressed their dissatisfaction of the kind of training their children were receiving at the present time.

If you approve the above application, will you be good enough to write to Father Latour to that effect.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Very sincerely yours,

[Signature]

November 15, 1943.
Ottawa,
November 17, 1943.

Mr. D.H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Sask.

A request has been received for the admission of Tobie Badger, Ida John and Marie-Josephine Gladu to the Blue Quills Residential School. From the information we have received there does not appear to be any reason why these children should not be admitted to a residential school. I should, therefore, appreciate your forwarding the necessary application forms.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

October 23rd, 1943.

Dear Father Latour,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 18th., instant, enclosing Applications for Admission of pupils to the Blue Quills School.

The applications for George McFeaters, Elsie Janvier and Mary Edna Mikosse, of Long Lake Reserve, have been completed and forwarded to Ottawa; also the request of Sam Badger, Keeheewin Reserve, for the transfer of his daughter Mary from St. Anthony's School to Blue Quills School, was forwarded from this office under date of October 5th., past.

With reference to the applications for the admission of Tobie Badger, Ida John, Mark and Josephine Gladue, of Keeheewin Reserve, I regret that it is impossible for me to recommend the admission of these children as they are already pupils of the Long Lake Indian Day School and I know of no reason why they should not be in attendance there. In this connection I would appreciate it if you would have these children returned to their parents with as little delay as possible.

With regard to Ella John, I am making further enquiries in this case and will advise you later. Her sister Therese, now sick in Bonnyville Hospital, is enrolled in St. Anthony's School.

Yours truly,

Donald H. Cameron,
Indian Agent.

Rev. L.C. Latour C.M.I.
Principal.
Blue Quills Indian Residential School.
ST. PAUL, Alberta.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources.
OTTAWA.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your 119-1-10 of the 17th., instant, with reference to the applications for admission of four children from Kesheewin Reserve to Blue Quills Residential School and to submit herewith( in addition to a copy of my reply to the Rev. Principal, Blue Quills School ) the following reasons for withholding my recommendation.

When I visited the Long Lake Indian Day School on September 27th., (Vide my report on this School forwarded through Mr Christianson's Office, at his request on Octr 5th,) I found only nine children on the roll and six present. The teacher intimated that an injunction was already on the reserve to have the school closed but I could obtain nothing definite on this point. However, I have since been informed reliably that the resident priest had told the farm instructor and the Indians many times that the school would be closed this fall, and I am also informed that unusual pressure was used to get the Indians to send their children to Blue Quills, with the result that only about seven were attending the Day School in October. I am of the opinion that to admit the children referred to would definitely ruin the Day School and their admission should not be contemplated as long as the Day School is in operation.

I visited the Long Lake School on November 23rd., and found that the children in question had been returned to the reserve from Blue Quills School and there were 14 on the roll and 10 in attendance on the morning I was there. I might add that Father Routhier, Provincial Father of Alberta, called on me on November 10th., when I explained the whole matter to him I believe, to his satisfaction.

Donald H. Cameron,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,

Saddle Lake, Alberta.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Attention Philip Phelan Esq., Chief, Training Division.

Re No. 347—Chas. Houle.

With reference to your letter of the 5th inst. I beg to state that Doctor Pecosan has not passed this boy's medical certificate owing to the child's eyes; this boy is proceeding to Edmonton on Feb. 10 to see an Eye Specialist. If his eyes are too bad to permit of his attendance to school, his account will be separate to the school charges. Pending this decision of the Eye Specialist, admission will be held up; otherwise the boy is physically fit.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Saddle Lake, Alberta.

5th March 1944.

I beg to enclose herewith three applications for admission of Indian Pupils to the Blue Quill's Indian School and would comment as follows:

John Delver. In order.

Florence Lameman. The father of this child requested that the child be put in school. He is now married the second time and his wife has left him and the home conditions for this child are not desirable.

Mathew Houle. You will note Doctor Armstrong's report re this boy's eyes. Father Latour has had this boy in school and the boy appears to like school and his doing his best. School will no doubt help the child considerably.

I would recommend the admission of the three children.

Eva Redcrow of No.58 Blue Quill's Band, for your information the mother of this child was admitted to the T.B. Wing of the St. Theresa Hospital on Jan.14th 1944, is a sick case and still in hospital. This left this girl with practically no home at all.

I would recommend both admissions.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

At the opening of the school year, pupil 0229, Emilia Bisson, of Cold Lake Reserve, has returned to this school with the other children. REPORT ON SADDLE LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH SEPTEMBER, 1944.

Blue Quill's School

The Return to school on Sept. 6th of the school children was very poor.

Father Letour had his milk cows inoculated against 7 and it turned out very poor and infection setting in on the whole 20, he lost one of his pure bred cows. His herd was T.B. Teasted by Doctor Harold Spence of the Dominion Health of Animals Branch.

Doctor Bissonette of St. Paul was the Veterinary that was responsible for the inoculation trouble. I visited the School on Sept. 12. I would have visited again on Sept. 29th but was away from the Agency.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Saddle Lake, Alta. 17th Oct. 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to herewith enclose quarterly school return for the quarter ending 30th September 1944, together with Admission & discharge return of pupils.

The Principal in his letter of the 16th October 1944 asked for the discharge of the following pupils,

273 Maxime Seenum,
0192 Angelique McGilvery,
038 Mary Margaret Cardinal,
N7-0255 Mary Madeleine Collins.

The above 4 pupils have reached the age of 16 years of age.

He is also requesting the discharge of the following pupils,

0272 Bernadette Brighteyes, going 16 and out of school for over a year.
0294 Emma Cardinal, 16 years old in October.
0308 Evangeline Cardinal, these two children attend now Vilna Country School, where their father lives.
0318 Mary Irene Cardinal

I would respectfully recommend the discharge of the above pupils.

The six applications for Admission which figure on the Quarterly Return have not yet been completed by Doctor Doose, it has just been impossible to get the Doctor to go to the school. The Doctor promised me he would get them examined this month.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 27, 1944.

3 Nov. 1944.

I beg to enclose herewith the following applications for admission as grant earning pupils to the Blue Quill's Indian School, as follows:

Margaret Laura Lagatok - No. 107, Blue Quill's Band, for your information the father of this illegitimate child was never definitely established and the grandmother Mrs. Gibeau who is a Treaty Indian of the Onion Lake Agency, is of none to worthy a character and the child always had a precarious living. I would recommend the admission.

John Albert Pasquayak, of No. 66 Blue Quill's Band.
Nathaniel Houle, of No. 231 James Seenum's Band.

The latter two are regular admissions and both are recommended.

W.F.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

With reference to the March quarter return of the Blue Quills Residential School, the Department approves the discharge of pupils numbered 359 and 0286.

It is noted that the pupils numbered as follows have not returned to the school for times varying between 9 and 18 months. If there is no prospect of any or all of these children returning in the near future, I feel it would be advisable to apply for their discharge, in order to permit their names being removed from the quarterly return. Sir,

Indian name of child
English name Emilia Bugle
Age 8
Name of Band Beaver Lake

Father's full name and No. Samuel Bugle (Peekeosis, No 103)
Mother's full name and No Alice Desjarlais (Peekeosis, No 103)
Parents living or dead Both living
State of child's health F.E. Good
Religion R.C.
Does applicant speak English? No
Previously attended No school for 8 years

(Signature of father)

Note—If mother or guardian signs, agent must forward full explanatory note.

Agent

Time of day: 3:30 PM

M.D.
Indian Affairs Branch - Ottawa.

I enclose herewith Applications for Admission of the following children to the Blue Quills R.C. Indian Residential School, St. Paul, Alberta.

Elie L. Minocse - Chipewyan Band
Marcel Piche -
John N. Janvier -
Jimmy Noel -
Frank Noel -
Irene Dion - Keeheewin Band
Mary Rose John -
Eva Skani - Chipewyan

With reference to the Application for Admission of Frank Noel, age 5, I wish to say that I have signed the application to have this child admitted as a grant earning pupil owing to the fact that his mother is a patient in the T.B. Sanatorium, Edmonton.

Father L. C. Latour, Principal, Blue Quills School, also requests the transfer of Helen Pascal, Pupil No. 0369, Onion Lake R.C. School, to the Blue Quills School, where she has been in residence since last fall. I have discussed the matter with Father Pascal, Principal, Onion Lake R.C. School and he is quite willing to have the girl transferred to Blue Quills. It is my opinion that it is advisable to have this transfer made.

Donald H. Cameron,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 1, 1947.

Mr. D.H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Sask.,

With reference to your letter of January 15th, the Department approves the admission of the following children to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School:

Elie L. Minoose,
Marcel Piche,
John N. Janvier,
Jimmy Noel,
Frank Noel,
Irene Dion,
Mary Rose John,
Eva Skani.

In view of the contents of your letter, the Department approves the transfer of Helen Pascal from the Onion Lake R.C. School to the Blue Quills Residential School. Please advise the Principals accordingly.

Philip Thelans,
Chief, Training Division.

St. Paul, Alta., October 26, 1946

Sir,

I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the Blue Quill Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child: Emma Sophia Mooswa
English name: Emma Sophia Mooswa
Age: 6 (December 24, 1940)
Name of Band: Saddle Lake
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid: No. 131
Father's full name and No.: Edward Mooswa
Mother's full name and No.: Emilie Cardinal
Parents living or dead: Both dead, child kept by Peter Cardinal, S.L., No. 131
State of child's health: Good
Religion: R.C.
Does applicant speak English?: No
Previously attended: No school for years

NOTE: This child is an orphan. The grandfather who has been keeping her is now a widow & unable to care for the child.

(Signature of father)

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

Signature of Missionary or other Witness

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

Ottawa, April 30, 1947.

Rev., L.C. Latour, O.M.I., Principal, Blue Quills Indian Residential School, St. Paul, Alberta.

With reference to the March Quarterly Return of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, it is noted that pupils No. 324, 0354 were absent during December but ninety days grant was requested in March. Also pupil No. 374 was in residence only seventy-two days. In these three cases the date the pupils returned to school is required.

Pupils Nos. 379, 0307 and 0346 were only in residence part of the Quarter. Please advise of the disposition of these three children and the dates of their absence.

The usual application forms and certificates of health are required for all new pupils shown on Form No. 411 with the exception of No. 0405 whose application has been received and approved.

The Department approves the discharge of the following pupils:

No. 0248 No. 0327 No. 0349.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

KB/HM.
Attention: Mr Philip Phelan;

I think, dear Sir, this will pretty well cover all the questions asked in your letter.

I notice your letter was addressed to Rev.L.C.Latour. May I bring to your kind attention the fact that Rev.L.C.Latour left the Blue Quills School on January 24, 1947. I am taking his place for the time being.

It would be very highly appreciated if the checks from now on would be made payable to me, instead of to him. It would save the trouble of remailing the checks to him to have them endorsed.

I remain, dear Sir:

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Rev. J. Bidault, O.M.I.
Acting Principal.
Blue Quills Indian Residential School  
St Paul, Alberta  
May the 8th, 1947

Dept. of Mines and Resources,  
Indian Affairs Branch  
Ottawa;  

Attention: Mr Philip Phelan  

Dear Sir:-

I am in receipt of your letter: 118-1-10 (W.T.7) dated April 30, 1947, and in reply I beg to give you the following informations:

Pupils No 324 and 0354, absent during December 1946, returned to Blue Quills School on January 1, 1947.

Pupil No 374 spent 18 days in St Paul's Hospital, from January 21, to February 8.

Pupil No 379 also spent 18 days in St Paul's Hospital, from February 12 to March 1st. Both pupils were ordered to the hospital by the local doctor, Dr Decosse, for special treatment.

Pupils No 0307 and 0346 have both been ordered after X-Ray examination, to the Charles Camell's Hospital, Edmonton for T.B. treatment, and they are still there to-day.

With regard to the last paragraph of your letter, I know that application forms and certificates of health are required for all new pupils. I fully intended to have them forwarded long before this. But our winter has been so severe, with roads impassable during February, March and April, that the Doctor has not been able to come to the School to make the regular examination of the pupils. I saw him to-day and he told me that he would be there soon then the applications will be forwarded to the Agent and the Department.

I wish to bring your kind attention to pupil 388. This child has been examined by the Doctor, and the application would have been forwarded long ago, had it not been for the obstination of the father in refusing to sign the application. He has been approached several times, both by the Agent and myself, and his answer is always the same: "I will not sign, until I am sure that the child likes it."

Correction shown on return and extra gram out.

Remarks on No. 390.- Archie Jacknife.

This pupil has not yet been admitted because, apparently, he does not belong to the treaty. Still I am trying to do my best, to have him admitted as grant earning pupil, under the plea that this poor child, adopted by Indian parents, will never have a chance for education any other way.

Ottawa, October 20, 1947.

Mr. W.K. Taylor, Indian Agent, St. Brides, Alberta.

We are in receipt of the September Quarter Return for the Blue Quill's Indian Residential School.

It is noted that ninety-two days grant has been requested for the under-mentioned children, who have not been in residence according to our records for over three quarters:

No. 346  
0322  
0325  
0345  
0373

Considering that these children were not in residence during the June Quarter, they are definitely not allowed ninety-two days grant. However, if they have returned to school they would be allowed grant from the date they returned.

We are withholding this Return until we receive the required dates in order to alleviate further confusion. In the course of the next few days we are forwarding a part payment of $4000.00 to assist the school.

The discharge of the following is approved:

No. 301  
No. 0334

Bernard F. Neary,  
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

Reference your letter of May 19th (1-1-0) and enclosure - Application for admission of a boy Archie Jacknife to Blue Quills School - I wish to advise that I have made enquiries and this boy is not of Indian status. Therefore I am returning the forms herewith.

Yours truly,

Donald H. Cameron,
Indian Agent.
OTTAWA, October 22, 1947.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

Enclosed please find the application of Mrs. Bella Cardinal, the foster mother of Archie Jacknife, asking that this child be admitted to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School. The application was refused by your agent, Mr. D. H. Cameron, on the grounds that the child is not a Treaty Indian.

The contention of the Principal of the school is that this child was adopted by Treaty Indians and as such has the same rights as an Indian child born of parents belonging to a Treaty. I, therefore, hope that you will be able to settle this contentious case to the satisfaction of the Principal of the Blue Quills Indian School.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
Ottawa, October 28, 1947.

Mr. Donald H. Cameron, Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

We have received a request for the admission of Archie Jacknife to the Blue Quills Residential School. We understand that this application has already received your consideration.

Please let me know the history of this boy in order that we can decide if he is eligible to be admitted as a grant earning pupil to an Indian Residential School.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

PP/MGD
To replace letter of Oct. 28th, addressed in error to Mr. Cameron.

Ottawa, October 29, 1947.

Mr. H.S. Packman, Clerk in Charge,
Indian Agency, Onion Lake, Sask.

We have received a request for the admission of Archie Jacknife to the Blue Quills residential school. We understand that this application has already received your consideration.

Please let me know the history of this boy in order that we can decide if he is eligible to be admitted as a grant earning pupil to an Indian Residential School.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

PF/MGD
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ont.

I have for acknowledgment Department letter 118-1-10 (WT1) dated 29th October.

On June 14, the Indian Agent at Saddle Lake Agency, was advised by this office that Archie Jacknife was not of Indian Status, and the application forms for admission were returned to the Saddle Lake Agency.

I understand that this boy's right name is Jack Paradis, his Mother's name is Roxana Paradis, and the boy was born in the Misericordia Hospital on March 25, 1935.

(H.S. Packman)
A/Indian Agent.
Ottawa, November 24, 1947.

Dear Father Plourde:

With reference to your letter of the 22nd ultimo regarding Archie Jacknife, we have communicated with the Indian Agent and are advised that this boy is not of Indian status and consequently his admission to an Indian Residential School as a grant earning pupil cannot be approved.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
University of Ottawa,
Laurier Avenue East,
Ottawa, Ontario.

January 24, 1948.

Mr. W.K. Taylor, Superintendent of Indian Agency,
St. Brides, Alberta.

We have your letter of the 16th instant requesting the discharge of Sophie Whiskyjack No. 0330 from the Blue Quill's Indian Residential School.

It is noted that you state the girl is needed at home. I presume that either the Principal or yourself made certain that her services were necessary and if so her discharge is approved.

However, I would point out to both the Principal and yourself that when a child reaches the age of sixteen it is not necessary to automatically discharge him. We have pointed out to the Principals from time to time that even if a child reaches sixteen during the academic term such child should be retained in the school until the end of the academic year namely June 30th.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

January 29, 1948.

Dear Father Holland:

The Department finds it necessary to return the December quarter return for the Blue Quills Residential School in order that you can supply us with additional information.

May I point out at the outset of this letter that these returns are very carefully checked not only by our own branch, but subsequently by the Auditor General and if the instructions contained on the outside of the return are not carried out and if the principal does not prepare the return in accordance with the instructions contained on the back of the return and in circular letter of December 29, 1944, a copy of which is enclosed, the additional information has to be received.

For the quarter ended September 30th, 1947 grant for 92 days was requested for pupils numbered as follows:

281, 295, 306, 313; 324, 325, 326, 327, 339, 363, 371, 375, 379, 0249, 0325, 0345, 0367, 0391,

In view of the fact that grant was requested for 92 days, the Department presumed that the children had been in residence at least during the month of September, 1947. In the case of all pupils allowed home on holidays at the end of June the school is entitled to grant in the September quarter for the 62 days holiday leave plus the number of days the pupil is actually in residence during the September quarter.
On checking the December quarter return we find that all the pupils shown above are stated to be at home. Are we to infer that these children did not return after the summer holidays or were they all allowed home on September 30th? If the latter is the explanation, please let me know why you found it necessary to allow so many of them to go home.

If the explanation is that they did not return to the school on the expiration of their summer holidays, grants should only have been requested during the September quarter for 62 days for each of them.

In the case of pupils numbered as follows: 384, 2077, 0279, 0298, 0328, 0329, 0331, 0332, 0337, 0340, 0341, 0342, 0343, 0347, 0348, 0350, 0351, 0352, 0353, 0354, 0357, the September quarter return requested grant for them for the full quarter and presumably they were in residence during that quarter. However, in none of these cases are you asking grant for the full December quarter and it is, therefore, presumed that the children have been allowed home in which case you should state the exact date on which they left the school.

In the case of pupil 386, you ask 85 days grant and you place under the remarks column, the following - "At Camsell Hospital Dec. 27". Does this mean that the boy was placed in the hospital on that date? If he was in the school from October 1st and was placed in the hospital on December 27th, you are entitled to ask grant for the full December quarter. What has been said regarding this boy applies also to pupil 401.

In the case of pupil 0364, you request grant for 29 days and state "In hospital from October 13 to November 27". This is a period of 45 days.
and as we allow thirty days hospital leave, grant should have been requested for this girl for seventy seven days.

I wish you would review the return in view of the information given in this letter and make any amendments you consider necessary and send back the return as soon as possible. In the meantime, to assist in your financing we have made a part payment of $4,000.00 on your December quarter grant.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. E. Bernet-Rolland, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Blue Quills Residential School,
St. Paul, Alberta.

I am forwarding this Application for Admission for your information. You will note this girl never attended any school, due mostly to the objection of the mother, who is now sorry.

Superintendent.

February 5, 1948

Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division,  
Welfare and Training Service,  
Department of Mines and Resources,  
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

The difficulties arising from our September and December Quarterly Returns are due partly to my inexperience, and partly to the special situation in which we were at the beginning of the school term.

The date of re-entrance was set at September the 1st, and we gathered a few children from Cold Lake, Legoff, Keeheewin and Beaver Lake. When we were ready to go and get the Saddle Lake's children, we were told by Mr. K.W. Taylor, Indian agent that due to an epidemic of measles, we would have the children only at a later date; at first it was on Sept. 15th, but at last with the complete approval of Dr. Stone, Regional Superintendent Health, Cassell's Hospital, the date was set at October the 15th.

When we prepared the quarterly Return, ending Sept. 30th, we considered September as continuation of the holidays for the Saddle Lake's children and gave them the number of days in residence accordingly, and under the item Attendance in class-room, we gave only the number of days to those then present.

For the December Return, after we had all the children, we realized that the children of "your first list" would not very likely return to school; we did not give
them any day in residence and we notified them as being at home, meaning that they were not officially discharged, and not in school.

The children mentioned in the second list are all from Saddle Lake, and the same reasons apply to their case. We considered they were in prolonged holidays in the September Return, and in the December Return, we began to count their residential days on October 16th, without asking the grant for the first 18 days of October. Although considering those eighteen days as extended holidays we should have asked the grant for the period.

The boy No. 386 came to School on the 24th of October, five days after the others, and if we consider the holidays ending on October 16th, he would be entitled to the grant for nearly all the Quarter.

Pupil 0564 re-entered School on October 13th, in the morning, and we had her ready to go to the Hospital in the evening. In the event of the school officially re-opening on October 16th, she would be entitled to the seventy-seven days you mentioned in your letter.

If that extension of the holidays period had been clearly stated, we would have avoided the major part of our difficulties.

By the way, it is the same reason that applies in answer to the question why the children of our school did not go home for their Christmas holidays. It was thought the School term had been quite short, and besides, sickness had not abated on the Reserve, at Christmas time.
Mr W R Taylor, agent, was on a regular visit here today and I brought the matter with him. He is of the same opinion that the late official entrance of the Saddle Lake's children does not seem to have been reported to the Department.

I would like to know at the earliest your decision on this matter and I would be ready to make accordingly a new return for December.

In closing I ask to remain,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

ATTENTION, Mr Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Div.

This will advise that I have very recently been contacted by the Rev. Father Rollande of Blue Quills Indian Residential School, with regards to Quarterly returns from his School. There appears to be somewhat of a misunderstanding, and Father Rollande advised me that he was not too familiar with the proceedings, as took place at this Agency during the September and December Quarters for 1947.

I will endeavour to outline the cause of trouble, and without a doubt the cause of errors for the two quarterly returns mentioned above.

Due to a serious epidemic of Measles in this Agency the Blue Quills Residential School was not opened officially, as the majority of the families were under Quarantine. This also effected the opening of the Edmonton Indian Residential School. The epidemic was handled under the supervision of Dr. Decosse, and his findings were reported to Dr. E. L. Stone, Regional Superintendent, Indian Health Services, Edmonton. As a result of the Quarantine the Blue Quills School did not open officially until October 15th, 1947.

As the Rev. Father Rollande was not acquainted with the proceedings he made his September returns out in such a way that the month of September, in the same quarterly returns, would be classed as extended leave. This was also substantiated by the fact that all preparations, including staff, were prepared for official opening on September 1st, 1947. Despite the fact the school could not be opened, some pupils were brought in to the School for the September Quarter from Beaver Lake end
(Lake and) Whitefish Lake Reserves in this Agency, and some pupils from the Reserves in the Onion Lake Agency.

The remaining pupils did not return until October 18th, 1947. When the December returns were made out, pupils that did not return and were attending School for the 2nd and 3rd Quarters, were shown as being at home. I regret that proceedings of this nature were new and strange to me, or same would have been checked before going this far, causing inconveniences in all sections.

May I please be advised what procedure should be taken. It would appear that the 3rd Quarterly returns would have to be re-submitted in order to rectify the December Quarterly returns. Every endeavour possible will be made to correct this matter at the earliest possible date.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.
February 14, 1948.

Dear Father Rolland:

We have your letter of the 5th instant with reference to the September and December quarter returns of the Blue Quills Residential School. We have decided not to review the September return and consequently no further action need be taken regarding it.

In connection with the December return, you should place opposite the names of those comprising the first list in my letter of January 29th the word "absent". Do not state "At home". This entry should be made in the column headed "Remarks".

With reference to the second list, you should ask grant for them from October 18th to December 31st inclusive and in the column headed "Remarks" you should place opposite the names the statement "Absent from school between October 1st and October 17th".

For pupil No. 386 grant should be requested from October 24th to the end of December. For pupil No. 0364 you should request grant for 77 days.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. E. Bernet-Rollande, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Blue Quills Indian Res. School,
St. Paul, Alberta.

PP/MGD
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Mr. R. A. Hoey  
Director of Indian Affairs Branch  
Department of Mines & Resources  
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

On February the 23rd, we were asking for the official discharge of a number of pupils who did not come back to our School. By error, we did not include the name of Peter COLLINS No 306, though he was mentioned for discharge on our Return for December. Presuming that his discharge would be granted we include his name on the here attached Form No. I.A.411., with the hope this will not cause any inconvenience.

May I take this opportunity to thank you for all you do in favor of our children, and specially for the financial increase of the per capita grant that will enable us to face the high cost of living and to start working on the improvements suggested by Miss McCready.

In closing I beg to remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Rev. E. Bernet-Rolland C.M.I.  
Principal.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Jean, Lena and Victoria Cardinal
children of Matthew Cardinal,
#228 Saddle Lake Band.

With reference to the above named children I wish to submit the following information for the consideration and ruling of the Department:

1. The parents of Jean, Lena and Victoria Cardinal wish to enroll their children in the Blue Quills Indian Residential School. These children, together with their parents belong to the Protestant faith, United Church of Canada. Lena and Victoria attended the Edmonton Indian School during the 1947-48 season. Jean has never attended school to date.

2. Before any action is taken by Rev. Father Rollande, O.M.I., Principal of Blue Quills Indian School, to have these children enrolled in his school, he would like a ruling on this particular case. That is, a protestant child enrolling in a Catholic School.

It would be very much appreciated if we could have your ruling on this case so that the parties concerned may be informed.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

RWW.
September 16, 1948.

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
St. Brides, Alta.

We have your letter of the 8th instant
with reference to Jean, Lena and Victoria Cardinal.

In view of the information contained in
your letter, these children are not eligible for
admission as grant earning pupils to the Blue Quills
Residential School. In this connection, I would re-
fer you to Section 10 (2) of the Indian Act.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

November 25, 1948.

Mr. G.H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of
Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alberta.

Re: School Children - Wabamum Reserve

With reference to your letter of November 6th, and my reply of November 18th, we are now advised that the thirteen children can be accommodated in the Blue Quills and Onion Lake R.C. Residential Schools.

As we infer from the contents of your letter of November 6th that these children are not receiving any education now, we would appreciate it if you would instruct Superintendent Robertson to arrange for the admission of the children to the two schools mentioned.

If at any time in the future a day school is established on the reserve, we can then consider whether the children should be allowed to remain at home to attend the day school.

Bernard Neary
Superintendent of Education.
B. F. Neary, Esq.,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Re: School Children - Wabunum Reserve.

I have just returned from the north to find your letter of November 25th, in which you instruct that the 13 R.C. children at Wabunum be admitted to the Blue Quills and Onion Lake R.C. residential schools.

On my trip I found both the Blue Quills and Ermineskin schools filled to capacity with a waiting list of children eligible to attend.

It may be that the Onion Lake school could accommodate these children but after discussing the matter with Superintendent Robertson, I am convinced that the parents would not agree to send their children such a great distance. Mr. Robertson mentioned this in his letter of November 19th, file 110-6-3 addressed to you.

As I mentioned in my letter of November 8th, Mr. Staley, principal of the Edmonton residential school, stated that he would be glad to take these children into residence if there was no objection. Frankly I can think of no other solution to this problem except the provision of temporary day school facilities presently under consideration. Unfortunately there are no buildings near enough to the centre of the population to be used for a temporary school.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.
December 15, 1948.

Mr. G.H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of
Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alberta.

School Children - Wahamum Reserve

It would seem, in view of the regulations of the present Indian Act, that the only way to provide school facilities for the children on the Wahamum Reserve, will be by the establishment of a small day school. It is unfortunate that no temporary accommodation exists and that the Department of National Defence will not release the buildings previously requested.

We are having our architects design a low cost one room school without a basement and which will be heated only by stoves. It is felt that such a building would provide adequate accommodation on a reserve in which we are uncertain as to the outcome of the operation of a day school.

We will have an opportunity of discussing this matter when you visit the Department in January.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Further to those listed above, the Rev. Principal has requested the re-admission of;

0358 - Joyce CARDINAL
0393 - Yvonne JOHN

With regards to the two re-admissions, I would recommend same for the following reasons. Joyce CARDINAL has been attending a School (Day) in Edmonton, and her mother is working as a Nurses Aide in the General Hospital. Mrs. Cardinal is now working nights, and unable to take care of her daughter. A request was made to have this girl placed in a Convent, but it was recommended that she complete her eighth Grade first. The parents of Yvonne John are of a roving nature, and have not given their daughter a fair chance. I feel she will do well if admitted to the Blue Quills School.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

October 7th., 1949.

Col. B.F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

The Principal of the St. Anthony's Indian Residential School has contacted this office and asked that Harry Martial, of Cold Lake, be re-admitted to the I.R.S.

This matter is herewith submitted for your approval. It may be stated that, last year, this child was in poor health and the Principal deemed it wise to discharge the boy and let him go home. Now it appears that the child is again in good health and wishes to return to school.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.
October 18, 1949.

Mr. G.S. Lapp,
Supt. Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.,

Rollande, Principal of the Blue Quills Indian School, asking for the official discharge of various pupils from his school, I wish to advise that there are two amendments to be made.

Since the quarterly return was made up and submitted to this office, the undermentioned pupils have returned to school. Would you therefore kindly delete them from the list of pupils for discharge mailed to you.

0391 Rema Frenchman - returned Jan 3/50
0409 Rosalie Whiskeyjack - returned Jan 3/50.

Your file 118/25-2
of January 30th

I have the application for admission of Lucille Eliza Cardinal to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

As you probably know the Blue Quills school is already over the authorized enrolment. The parents of this child are both living. It is, therefore, impossible to approve the admission of this pupil at this time.

The matter should again be brought to the attention of the Department during the summer when some of the present pupils will be discharged.

Philip Phelan,
Acting Superintendent of Education.

April 4th, 1951.

Rev. E. Bernet-Rolland, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Blue Quills Indian Residential School,
St. Paul, Alberta.

Dear Father Rollande:

We have your letter of the 27th ultimo with reference to Annie and Doris Collins.

While there are many children of non-Indian status who would like to attend Indian Residential Schools, at the same time it must be kept in mind that the funds provided by Parliament are intended for the education of recognized Indian children only. Consequently, we cannot make an exception in the case of the two Collins girls, and they should be discharged in the immediate future.

As a matter of fact, they should never have been admitted to the Blue Quills Residential School which is a government-owned building, and as intimated above, is intended to be used for the education of recognized Indian children only.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education

enclosure.
October 4, 1951.

Mr. W.E. Taylor,
Supt., Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.,

This refers to your letter of September 26, file 118/25-2-751 regarding the transfer of pupils from the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

Frankly, it is not clear to this office the reason for this transfer. Our records indicate that both of the schools are over the authorized pupilage.

You indicate that these children have been in the Onion Lake School from two to nine years. As the Course of Study for Saskatchewan is somewhat different from that of Alberta, we are of the opinion that children who have been at the Onion Lake School for seven to nine years should complete their education there. The others may be transferred provided one or both of the schools are prepared to absorb the transportation costs for these children.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

October 18, 1951.

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Supt. Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.,

This refers to your letter of September 29th regarding admissions to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

The Department approves the admission of all pupils listed in your letter except the four Cardinal children whose names are Victoria, Lena, Gene Francis and Emily as these pupils are Protestants and according to our records Victoria and Lena have attended the Edmonton school. The application shows that Gene Francis also attended the Edmonton school but we are unable to verify this from the Edmonton return. Would you advise the enrolment number of this pupil when attending the Edmonton school.

The Principal, Father Rollande should not have admitted the Cardinal children to the Blue Quills school until their admission was approved.

As the admission of the Cardinal children to the Blue Quills school is not approved, grant for them for the September Quarter is not allowed. You may advise the Principal to this effect.

The discharge of pupils numbered 392, 0329 and 0379 is also approved.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
October 18, 1951.

Rev. Bernet-Hollande, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Blue Quills Indian Res. School,
St. Paul, Alta.,

Dear Father Rollande:

This refers to the September Quarterly return for the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

On Form I.A. 411 enclosed with this Return you indicated that three pupils have been discharged during this quarter and that no admissions have been made.

On checking the Return, it is noted that in the margin you have shown that seventeen pupils are being discharged and forty-one pupils were either admitted for the first time or re-admitted after being absent for some time.

You are advised that you must show on Form I.A. 411 all pupils you propose to discharge and those you admitted during the quarter, whether the admissions and discharges have been approved or not.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Attention: Superintendent of Indian Education.

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant under file 751-10-(F6) in regard to transfer of Indian pupils from Onion Lake Residential School to Blue Quills Indian Residential School we wish to advise that Ellyse and Lawrence Martial were admitted to the Onion Lake Indian Residential School at the ages of five and three respectively and that they have attained the grades of four and one respectively. The parents of these children strongly insist that these pupils be taught this year at Blue Quills School because they believe these children will advance more quickly here and that it will be much easier for the parents to visit them and also that the children would be able to return home during the holidays included in the school year. We also wish to advise that the same circumstances exist with regard to Nora Desjarlais.

In the case of Wilhelmina Ennow it appears that this girl, who is not sixteen years of age, was becoming very difficult to handle and the parents believe they could be in closer contact with her should she be allowed to attend Blue Quills School.

This matter has been fully discussed with Father Hollande and he informed us that he is quite ready to accept these pupils should the Department give their approval. Transportation cost in this regard will be paid by the parents concerned.

We would strongly recommend transfer of the above mentioned children, if at all possible.

W. K. Taylor, Superintendent.
October 22, 1951

attention: Supt. Indian Education.

With reference to your letter of October 18th., under file 751-10(Eb), in regard to the four Cardinal children from this Agency who are, at present, in the Blue Quill Residential School, we wish to advise that the parents and children in this family are now following the Catholic faith. The younger children in this family have already been baptised and the older children and parents are receiving instruction in the R.C. faith. Since this family undertook the instruction under the R.C. faith before these children were enrolled in school we respectfully request that these admissions be approved as submitted and the grant for the September be allowed.

Three of the above children were previously enrolled in the Edmonton Residential School and their numbers were as follows: Victoria - 0301, Lena - 0302, Emily - 0307 and there is no record of Gene Francis having attended this school.

Father E.B. Rollande has been advised to show the above children on his quarterly return temporarily pending a further decision in this matter. Your further advice would be greatly appreciated in this matter.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.
January 9, 1952.

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Supt., Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.,

Your file 118/25-2-751

With reference to your letter of January 2nd regarding the admission of the four Cardinal children to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, you are advised that the Department is reviewing their case along with some fifty similar cases and when a definite decision is reached on the interpretation of the Indian Act in this regard you will be advised.

These children should not be entered on the December Quarterly Return for the Blue Quills school. If the Return is on its way to Ottawa by the time you receive this letter these children's names will be deleted from the Return and no grant will be allowed. Should a decision reached by the Department favour placing these children in the Blue Quills school the Returns will be amended in the future.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

January 23, 1952.

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Supt. Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.,

Further to our letters of October 18th and January 15th regarding the admission of the Cardinal children to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, it is noted from our files that three of the children were in the Edmonton Indian Residential school; two for four years and one for one year. It appears that these pupils were later discharged from the Edmonton school and all were placed in the Saddle Lake Day School.

It is noted from the application forms that both parents are living. Would you advise the necessity for institutional care for these children. It is noted that the children are already at the Blue Quills school, however, their admission to this school has not been approved and no grant can be allowed until the matter is cleared up.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attention: Supt. Indian Education.

With reference to your letter of the 23rd ultimo, under file 751-10(E6), in regard to the necessity of institutional care for the Cardinal children, this will advise that this is a large family which has 7 children living and three that died since 1949. The mother in this family is in very poor health and is constantly in the hospital. We consider that institutional care for these children would ease that burden on these parents to a great extent.

While these children were in the Saddle Lake Day School, this family needed the constant help of their neighbors to manage all their children.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.
February 12, 1952

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Supt. Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.,

Your file 118/25-2-751

With reference to your letter of February 5th regarding the Cardinal children, would you kindly advise whether these children are now at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

It is very doubtful that we will be able to secure approval for the admission of these children to the Blue Quills school. It would be appreciated if you would advise whether it would be possible to have these children placed in the Edmonton school where three of them were prior to attending the Saddle Lake Day School. Also advise under what circumstances these three children were taken out of the Edmonton school and placed in the Saddle Lake school bearing in mind the contents of your letter of February 5th.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Attention: Superintendent of Education.

Reference your letter of even file dated the 12th ultimo regarding the admission of the Cardinal children to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

On reviewing our files it is noted that the first correspondence in regard to this case was submitted September 8, 1948, under file 118/6-1 and a reply was received from your office under file 118-1-10 (E1) on September 16, 1948.

The father of this family, Matthew Cardinal, treaty No. 228 Saddle Lake Band, was born and raised as a member of the United Church. Shortly after he was married he was baptised and became a member of the Roman Catholic Church. There are eight children and all were baptised in the Roman Catholic Church with the exception of Victoria and Lena, who were baptised in the United Church. Victoria and Lena attended the Edmonton Indian Residential School for approximately three years and everything went well until it was time for Jean, the third daughter, to start school. It was then the parents requested a change and thus our letter of September 8th, 1948, to the Department for a ruling. The reason given by the parents for not wishing to have their children attend the Edmonton Indian Residential School was the fact that they, the parents, were now members of the Roman Catholic faith. Acting on your ruling of September 16, 1948, file number quoted above, the three girls were sent to the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

The following year when a new day school continued..............
was opened at Saddle Lake the parents of this family lived within a distance of one mile from the school and thus their children attended the Saddle Lake Day School.

During the spring of 1950 the parents moved to a new location approximately five miles from the Saddle Lake Day School and again requested that their children be admitted to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School. Since the beginning of the school term 1951, four children of this family have been attending the Blue Quills Indian Residential School. At the present time there is not sufficient room in the Edmonton Indian Residential School for the four girls and in view of the circumstances I would recommend that they be admitted to the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

The Principal of the Blue Quills School informed me that, should these children be allowed to attend this school, the two oldest girls will be baptised under Roman Catholic faith.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

With reference to the June Quarterly Return for the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, please advise the Principal that the Department allows 30 days hospital grant for pupils admitted to hospital during the quarter.

In the case of pupil #426, the Principal has indicated that this child was in hospital from March 29 to May 7th. Please advise the Principal that we have allowed 82 days grant rather than 54 as claimed by him. This increase was made as follows - pupil was in residence 54 days - 28 hospital grant was allowed on the March Quarter and 28 days on the June Quarter.

Pupil #0352 was in residence for 43 days. We have allowed 30 days hospital grant effective May 13, the date this pupil was admitted to hospital.

The Principal has claimed 50 days grant for pupil #0355. We have allowed 80 days grant which is 30 days beyond May 20 which is the date the pupil was admitted to the Charles Camell hospital.

Please advise the Principal of these corrections in order that he may be guided when preparing future returns.

Philip Phelan,

August 1, 1952.

INDIAN AFFAIRS

Rev. Father Rollands,
Principal, Blue Quill's Res. School,
ST. PAUL, Alberta.

Re: School Admission, Evelyn Black,
Tri 24, January Band, age 5 years.

Dear Rev. Father Rollands:

We have a child, the above, who is at present in the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital where both her parents are confined. She has no home to go to. It has been suggested by Dr. W.L. Falconer, Medical Superintendent, Indian Health Services, that she be sent to your institution.

In anticipation of your acceptance of this child we are having the parents sign her admission form which, in due course, a copy will be forwarded to you. It is assured that with the recommendation of Dr. Falconer her admission will be approved by the Indian Affairs Branch. It is rather urgent that she proceed at once to your school.

I am taking the responsibility of doing this, pending formal approval from Ottawa and with your acceptance of her. School admission forms are being sent to the Camsell Hospital, with a copy of this letter for signature.

Please advise this office if you can accept this child now.

Yours very truly,

H.M. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

October 20, 1952.

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Supt. Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.,

With reference to the September Quarterly Return for the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, the Department approves the discharge of the following pupils:

# 351 # 424 # 0381
371 429 0417
377 431 0463
384 0352 0472
0488

Pupil # 0355 according to the June Quarterly Return left this school to be admitted to hospital on May 20. As this pupil was not in residence during the month of June, the school is not entitled to per capita grant for July and August. We have, therefore, disallowed the sixty-two days grant for this pupil claimed by the Principal.

The Principal has neglected to indicate the date pupil # 0362 was re-admitted to the Blue Quills school after discharge from the Charles Camseil Hospital. It is presumed that the date was September 1, 1952. Please advise.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Applications for Admission
Blue Quills Indian Residential School
ST. PAUL, Alberta.

Attached find Application for Admission forms completed on behalf of Angelica Ann Kootenhayoo, age 7, TN 102 Alexis Band; Albert Sam Kootenhayoo, age 4, TN 102 Alexis Band and Zella Sarah Arcand, age 12, TN 164 Alexis Band. The father of these children, Joe Kootenhayoo is a patient in the Charles Camseil Indian Hospital, mother deserted these three children.

The father arrived with these children at the Charles Camseil Indian Hospital where he was urgently wanted for admission and the hospital authorities did not know what to do with the children. It has been found difficult or impossible to locate foster parents. In the emergency that arose they were placed in the Blue Quills Indian Residential School and they were accepted much to our satisfaction.

It was recommended that these children be admitted as grant earning pupils.

H.N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

Re: Children - Madeline Hainault
Your File 171/25-2

Mr. Woodsworth, Superintendent of the Edmonton Agency, has referred the above case to the department in order that instructions might be issued for the placement of these children in the Blue Quills Indian Residential School. However, before taking steps to have the R.C.M.P. act in this matter, it is thought that application forms for the admission of the children to the residential school should be signed, if possible, by the mother. This would simplify matters considerably.

If, for any reason, this is not practical, I shall appreciate your informing me why and steps will be taken to have the Blue Quills Residential School designated the one to which these children should attend.

Superintendent of Education

OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Application for Admission -
Blue Quill's Indian Res. School
St. Paul, Alberta.

Attached find Application for Admission Ralph Frederick Callihoo, age 12 years, TN 122 Michel Band.

This boy, along with his brother, was admitted to the Ermineskin Indian Residential School in September, 1952. He, along with his brother, repeatedly ran away and the Principal, Rev. Father Latour, discharged both boys. Rev. Father Rollande at Blue Quill's Indian Residential School, St. Paul, Alberta, took this boy in, after it was decided to split the boys and send one to Blue Quill's and one to Sturgeon Lake. The children have no mother and the father is unable to look after them. Both boys of Archie Callihoo have had little or no education and are a constant problem to the Michel Band community and to other communities in which they periodically reside. No one seems to be willing to foster them.

Action was taken, in view of this boy's lack of a home, to send him to Blue Quill's before submission of this application, which was January 29/53. It is hoped this action will meet with your approval.

Medical Examination has already been completed. See Application to Ermineskin Indian Residential School, in September 1952.

H.M. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

Re: Application for Admission
George Francis, son of Maggie Francis, TN 63 Heart Lake Bds.

Attached find application signed by Maggie Francis, mother of the above mentioned Indian child requesting admission of George to the Blue Quill's Indian Residential School in September 1953.

This child is recommended for admission by Dr. W.L. Falconer, Medical Superintendent, Indian Health Services. George has spent some time in the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital and it is important that he receives better care than he is receiving and has received at his home. It is also important he be educated. I am sure you will approve of the recommendations of Dr. W.L. Falconer in which I concur.

H.N. Woodsworth,

DEPARTMENT OF CITIZENSHIP AND IMMIGRATION
Edmonton Agency
403 Post Office Bldg.,
EDMONTON, Alberta.
May 20, 1953.

Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Application for Admission - Blue Quill's Indian Residential School.
George James and Barbara Ann Brule, TN
357 Bigstone Band

Attached find Applications for Admission, Blue Quill's Indian Residential School, submitted by the mother of the two above mentioned Indian children.

The mother recently prevailed on the Principal of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, to take them in. Evidently they only remained 10 weeks and were removed from the institution by the mother who considered the children unhappy there.

Attached find a copy of letter from Mr. G.S. Lapp, Superintendent, Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency, March 3, 1952, supporting their admission as requested by the mother at that time.

The father, George Stamp, Treaty #252 Enoch's Band, is constantly in jail and the situation regarding the care of these children has worsened rather than bettered. I, therefore, recommend their admission as requested by the mother to the Blue Quill's School where they can receive satisfactory care.

H.N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

enclosure
Mr. Narcisse Mustus, (Leslie Jones)
Glenavon, Alberta.

Res Clyde (Jones) Mustus
Andy (Jones) Mustus

In a letter dated July 27, 1953 Dr. W. L. Falconer, Medical Superintendent, Indian Health Services, recommends that Clyde and Andy be admitted to an Indian Residential School in September 1954 so that they may be under supervision and restricted activity which will hasten their return to health following the convalescence from T.B.

I agree with Dr. Falconer, however, you must make the decision. If you sign the attached application for admission forms, we will try and get your boys into the Blue Quill's Indian Residential School at St. Paul, Alberta. I am sure there they will be well cared for and receive good education and proper care which, because of your large family, you cannot give.

If you agree, return the signed forms to this office.

July 29th 1953.

Mr. G.H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
620 Public Building,
Calgary, Alberta.

Dear Mr. Gooderham,

Attached is a letter written by Mr. Dew, for your information, which explains itself.

We would appreciate anything you can do to further action these two patients.

Yours very truly,

W.L. Falconer M.D.
Medical Superintendent.

c.c. Dr. P.E. Moore.
Charles Camsell Indian Hospital,
Edmonton, Alberta.

July 25, 1953.

Mr. Gooderham,
Regional Superintendent of Indian Agencies,
620 Public Building,
Calgary, Alberta.

ATTENTION: Mr. Waller

Dear Mr. Gooderham,

We have two patients in the hospital who are giving us some concern at the present time. These patients are ready for discharge but will require a year's convalescence, preferably under a more restricted routine than they would experience in their own homes. The medical staff would like to hold them in hospital and over-treat them, but as they have a long list of active tuberculosis cases waiting to be admitted they have no choice but to prepare them for discharge.

These patients have no homes of their own to which they may return, but will have to live with friends or relatives if discharged home. Both of these patients are anxious to receive more education so that eventually they may receive training that would enable them to become gainfully employed.

Both patients are Indians, one 19 years of age and the other is 20 years of age. Both are Roman Catholics. I have canvassed all the private schools in Edmonton, with the hope that one or more of them would be prepared to accept at least one of these patients. However, the lowest grades taught in these schools is nine and ten. This is no help to us. As far as I can ascertain, there are no other institutions in Alberta where they can receive rest and training at the same time.

Therefore, can you help us? If there is room I would suggest that these two boys should attend Blue Quills Residential School. One of these patients, John Fournier, is unusually talented in art and it has been recommended that he eventually receive training in commercial art. I recall that when I visited Blue Quills School, that I was introduced to a very capable art teacher who would be able to give John much assistance.

2...
As I mentioned earlier, the need for beds is urgent and until some arrangement can be made for these boys, they must continue to occupy beds that are required by other patients. Could you therefore give me an answer as soon as possible, as to what assistance you can offer.

I realize that Residential Schools are for children, but as nothing is available for these adults following discharge, it would seem that the residential school provides the only solution to our problem until such time as the departments concerned with the native peoples set up such a training institution.

I am enclosing a summary of these patients for your information.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) FRED N. DEW

Principal.

9 September, 1953.

Mr. G.H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor,
628 Public Building,
Calgary, Alberta.

Margaret Paul daughter of Henry Paul TNL55 Alexander.

The father of the above mentioned Indian girl has requested his daughter be allowed to attend the Cherhill Day School. Margaret will live with Mr. and Mrs. Joe Klepadlo, Cherhill. Mr. Klepadlo is a farmer who will be working in saw mills in the winter and Margaret will earn her board by housework part-time and also learn from Mrs. Klepadlo this important measure of raising living standards. The Klepadlo's have two young children.

It is recommended Margaret be allowed to take her Grade VII at this school rather than at Blue Quills where her father originally intended to place her and to which installation her admission has already been approved.

cc Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

H.M. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.
September 14, 1953.

Mr. H.N. Woodsworth,
Supt. Indian Agency,
403 P.O. Bldg.,
Edmonton, Alta.,

With reference to your letter of September 9th, it is noted that institutional care for Margaret Paul daughter of Henry Paul is no longer required.

It will be in order for you to arrange for her attendance at Cherhill School rather than the Blue Quills School as originally authorized.

R.F. Davey,
Acting Superintendent of Education.

The Quill's Boarding School, P.C., Saddle Lake

Principal - Father Dauphin.

Visited School Feb 19th, 20th and April 13th.

Attendance - Total 51.
Girls 27 - Boys 24.

583928

Ventilation - good. Schoolrooms warm.
Do not have fire drill.

Cleanliness of school - very clean in every detail.
Visited kitchen - dormitories, pantries, dining-room, and class rooms spotless.

Schoolroom - bright, cheery and well ventilated.
Seats and desks too small for some of the children.

Dormitories - Rather crowded - clean and well ventilated.
No preliminary for sick children - they are kept in the dormitory.

Dining-room - One main dining-room for children. Children eating at different tables.

Food - abundant, well cooked and nicely served.
Breakfast - porridge & milk - bread - bacon or stew for older children. Little children drink milk.
Luncheon soup - meat and gravy - potatoes, bread and baked apple pudding.
Tea Cottage pie - Bread - stewed fruit and biscuits.

Children appear happy, are well nourished and well kept.

Illness - Several of the children had colds.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

H.E. Perry
Travelling Nurse

W.H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner
Ottawa.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith reports by Nurse Gerry on the Good Fish Lake Day School, Saddle Lake Day School and Blue Quills Boarding School, all in the Saddle Lake Band.

The reports show that the Indians are taking an interest in the schools.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) W. A. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Department Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, August 5th, 1923.

Dear Sir,

Your quotation on drugs required for Blue Quills Boarding School, Saddle Lake Agency, f.o.b. Ashmont, Alta., amounting to $182.09, is accepted.

You have quoted on 500 Quinine Tablets, Grs. 5¢. Kindly substitute for this, 500 Aspirin Grs. 5¢, as there is already included in the requisition an item for Quinine.

Kindly fill the order and ship to The Principal, Blue Quills Indian Boarding School, Ashmont, Alta. Your account in triplicate should be sent to Mr. J.E. Pugh Esq., Indian Agent, Saddle Lake, Alta.

Yours truly,

F.H. Paget
Accountant and Purchasing Agent.

Messrs. Chandler & Fisher Ltd.,
Winnipeg, Man.
CHANDLER & FISHER LIMITED

BRANCHES: VANCOUVER, B.C., EDMONTON, ALTA.

WINNIPEG, Aug. 13th, 1923.

The Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Attention of Accountant & Purchasing Agent-

Dear Sir,-

-referring to #118-1-13-

We beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant advising us that our quotations for the Blue Quill's Boarding School have been accepted.

This order will receive prompt attention and will go forward without delay. The shipping instructions have been noted.

Thanking you for the order, we remain,

Yours very truly,

CHANDLER AND FISHER, LIMITED.

Sec'y Treas.

Blue Sulli's Boarding School, R.C.

Principal,- Salvation Father
Sister Superior,- Courmayeur-Scottis

Visited the School, September 26th, 1923.
Attendance,-53.

Visited the whole building, kitchen, pantries, dormitories, classrooms, recreation rooms and dining-room, found everything very clean.

The dormitories are rather crowded, the children now have tooth-brushes and individual mugs for cleaning the teeth.

No sick children at present in the school, one child has suppurating glands as will be seen by the individual report enclosed, several of the children were put on a tonic.

Teeth,- several small cavities found, several cases for extraction, a list of cases left with the Sister in charge.

Food abundant.

Menu for the Day,- being Friday, no meat served.

Breakfast,- porridge with milk, potatoes, bread and butter,

Dinner,- Cottage pie without meat, bread and butter, milk pudding tea or milk to drink. Pea-soup.

Tea,- Potatoes and fish baked, spread and butter, and ginger-cake.

The children all seem very happy, and play well.

I have the honor to be, Sir

Your obedient servant,-

Traveling Nurse.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
REGINA, SASK.

THE SECRETARY:
Forwarded for your information.

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Telegraph Creek School for the Quarter ended... Sept... 1923.

Teacher... R.T. Pollock

P.O. Address... Telegraph Creek, B.C.

Dated... Sept... 1923.

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

H. Scott Macdonald
Indian Agent or Superintendent.

Dated at Telegraph Creek, B.C.
this... Sept... 1923.

Agents and Superintendents should see that full explanations are given by the teacher in the column for "Remarks," if the school was closed during the quarter for other than authorized holidays, and should also themselves make any necessary comments in that column.

INSTRUCTIONS TO TEACHERS

1. Fill up all the columns in this Return.
2. All the columns of the Return must be added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.
3. The total number of days absent and days present not to be omitted, as these two columns added together should give the total number of school days.
4. Number and date of holidays to be inserted in the column for remarks.
5. By the total number of school days in the quarter is meant the number of days in the quarter exclusive of Saturdays and Sundays.
6. The class standards of each pupil must be signified by inserting opposite his or her name the figure 1 in the column denoting the particular standard. The curriculum to be followed is that prescribed by the Department of Education for the province in which the school is located.
7. No names other than those of Indian children are to be included in this Return.
8. The Quarterly Returns must end on the 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December respectively, and be immediately thereafter in each case transmitted to the Department through the local Indian Agent or other authorized official.
9. When, owing to the number of pupils, the form of Return is not long enough to contain all the names, use another form, paging it as No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns. Do not increase the length of the form by pasting another, or portion of one to it.
10. The average daily attendance during the quarter may be ascertained by dividing the total number of days' attendance of all the pupils by the number of days school was open in the quarter.
11. No teacher's salary will be paid until this Return has been received by the Department.
12. Should the school be closed at any time during the quarter, the reason must be given in the column for remarks for such day or days.
13. The school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department.
14. This form to be used for Day Schools only.

NOTE.—The Indian Day School Regulations and Programme of Studies, as set forth on the back cover of the Daily Register, must be strictly followed by teachers of Indian Day Schools.

I have the honor to state that I have on necessity sent in to the Edmonton General Hospital, a boy (Johnson Large) pupil of the Blue Quills Residential School.

This was done acting on Dr Hardy's advice, as the boy was suffering from Cornea of the eye. His treatment will last about ten days to two weeks.

I trust that my action will meet with the approval of the Department.

I have the honor to be,
Sir,

Indian Agent.
Sir,

I have the honour to submit herewith in triplicate, requisition for drugs for use at the Blue Quill's Residential school in this Agency.

In regard to this requisition, I beg to draw your attention to the following items which in my opinion, are asked for in excessive quantities, viz:- 5 galls. White Pine Cough Syrup; Gauze - 100 yds., and Hot Water Bottles (1 qt.) 4, and I would suggest that one half the quantity asked for in each case would be sufficient for their requirements.

I also note that one Hypodermic Outfit is asked for and in regard to this item, I might state that I do not believe that an outfit such as this is necessary at the present time.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
