Indian Affairs, School Files (RG 10, Volume 6348, File 751-23, part 1)

Public Archives Canada
Visited this school June 23rd and 24th, 1924.

Sister Cournoyer is still in charge, conditions are much the same around the school, visited the entire building and out buildings, kitchen, ice house, pantries, dormitories, class-rooms, recreation and dining rooms.

Dormitories.- The boys are having new mattresses (made of wool) as the old straw ones are not fit for use.

Dining-room,- was clean and well aired.

Menu for the day,-

Breakfast,- porridge with milk and sugar, milk to drink bread and a fat.

Dinner,- Soup, meat and potatoes, bread, tea, and a cottage pudding.

Tea,- Hash in a meat pie, bread, stewed fruit and tea. Milk if wanted.

Health,- Fair, several of the children are carrying a temperature daily, Alice Cardinal had a T.F.R.104/98/18, asked the Sister to take her temperature daily and report the case if necessary. Helen Cardinal has swollen glands so has a temperature, asked that this child be given an extra allowance of milk, also Iron Tonic. Edmund Skunk, complains of a pain in the chest asked the Sister to watch the case. Eleanor Mountain, hip shorter than the other, complains of pain at times, would advise that she be examined by the Doctor.

Skin,- several cases of itch found advised the Sister to use a wash of Blue-stone and then an ointment, using special attention to the children's underwear.

Throats and Noses.

Several cases of bad tonsils noticed,

Madilda Quin
Veronique Menenock
Anna Houle
Eliza Stienbauer
Solomon Cardinal
Alex Doghead
Edmund Skunk

Emilia Pepekwanis
Eleanor Mountain
Veronique Large
Helena Cardinal
Albert Cardinal
Samuel Skunk
Leo Mountain

F. Cardinal
Blue Quill's School cont'd.

Nose and Throat, cont'd,
Francis Cardinal Louis Stienhaus
Norman Crane

Ears,- Hearing good.
Veronique Menenock had suppurating ears these I irrigated and asked the Sister to see that it was done until the condition improved.

Eyes; several cases of defective vision found,-
Matilda Quin Helen Cardinal
Mary Ann Shirt Marguerite Shirt
Angelique Houle Bella Rain
Marguerite Redcrow Veronique Large
Napoleon Brighteyes Julian Lapatak
Edward Cardinal

Heads,- only fair as to cleanliness, several cases of nits found these cases were pointed out to the Sister in charge.

Teeth,- Some extractions needed.

Left a list all cases with which the Doctor's attention should be called.

In the case of Napoleon Brighteyes, as the condition of his eyes is not improving under present treatment, I would advise hospital treatment.

I have the honor to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,-
[Signature]
Travelling Nurse.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner.
Regina, SASK.

Blue Quill's Indian Boarding School, Saddle Lake, Alberta.

Visited this school December 15th and 16th, 1924.

Found everything as usual, place not as clean as usual owing to a shortage of water, all the wash water had to be melted. The general health of the children appeared very good.

One child, Sylvester Cardinal, had a peculiar spell, no doubt partly due to a nervous and hysterical condition, this is the second of the nature, advised that the Doctor should be notified so that he could examine the child on his next visit to the school.

Gaston Large, the little lad is in very bad condition, has been in bed now for some time, is under the Doctor's care.

Asked that the Doctor should make an examination of Napoleon Brighteyes' eye case, to see if anything can possibly be done for this child as the condition is distressing.

Left a complete copy of the Individual Report of children, with the Indian Agent, to be checked up by the Doctor on his next visit to the School.

As will be seen by the enclosed Individual Report, general health of the children good.

Eyes.- Napoleon Brighteyes,-granular lids.

Defective Vision,-
Bella Rain Matilda Quinn, Mary Ann Shirt.
Veronique Large Napoleon Brighteyes

Nose and Throat.- Tonsils abnormal.
Matilda Quinn Edmund Skunk Albert Cardinal
Helena Cardinal Irene Brighteyes Francis Cardinal
Anna Houle Alex Doghead Samuel Skunk
Veronique Large Eleanor Mountain Leo Mountain.

Heads,- very fair, not as clean as usual.

Teeth,- Several extractions needed.
Several cavities found.

Skin,- Very good, one case of eczema, Veronique Large.

Glands,- good at time of visit.

I have the honor to be Sir,-
Your obedient servant,

Traveling Nurse.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

I beg to enclose herewith Travelling Nurse Gerry's report of her visit to the Blue Quill Residential School in the Saddle Lake Agency during the month of December last.

Your obedient servant,

Re. quotation on drug supplies for Blue Quills Indians enclosed herewith. P.D.&Co. Ovarian Substance Tablets list at $3.30 per 100 tablets, the quantity of 500 appears to us rather unusual.

RJH/KHC.

Ottawa, September 4th, 1925.

Dear Sirs,

Your quotation on drugs required for Indians of Blue Quills Indian Residential School, f.o.b. Ashmont, Alta., amounting to $307.40 is accepted. I beg to refer you to the last item "6 boxes J & J Strengthening Plasters" which kindly reduce to 3 boxes, thereby reducing your quotation to the amount stated.

I have also to point out that you omitted to quote on the following:
- 2# sulphur Ointment
- 2# eczema ointment for children
- 2# Ointment for Impetigo

Kindly send these with the order.

Shipment should be made to The Principal of the School, Ashmont, Alta.

Your account in triplicate should be sent to Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Indian Agent, Saddle Lake, Alta.

Yours truly,

F.H. Paget
Chief Accountant and Purchasing Agent.

Messrs. Revillon Wholesale Ltd.,
Edmonton, Alta.

Dear Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith for certificate an account from the Revillon Wholesale Ltd., for one gross Lifebuoy soap supplied to the Saddle Lake Residential School. In this connection I beg to state that this item was included in the requisition for drugs received under cover of your letter of the 3rd August last, No. 17, but it is thought that as the quantity is so large that it is used for other purposes than in the infirmary. If such is the case, the cost of the soap so used should be paid by the institution from their earnings. The Department is willing, however, to supply a limited quantity of carbolic soap for use exclusively for the sick.

Yours truly,

F.H. Paget
Chief Accountant and Purchasing Agent.

J.E. Pugh Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Saddle Lake, Alta.

Enclos.
Sir:-

I beg to report that Dr. Desosse has informed me that on his last visit at the Blue Quill's Residential School, he examined several pupils and found that they had enlarged tonsils. He recommends that these be removed and suggests that in the event of permission being granted the best method of dealing with these cases would be to have them taken to hospital at St. Paul where he could perform the necessary operations and keep the patients under observation for a few hours or possibly overnight.

The doctor considers that there would be about twelve cases requiring attention. I should be glad to have your authority in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) W. E. Gullion

Indian Agent.

W. M. Graham Esq.
Indian Commissioner
Regina Sask.
Sir:

I enclose a copy of a letter I have received from Mr. W. B. Gullion, Indian Agent at Saddle Lake, with reference to the desirability of operating on twelve pupils at the Blue Quill's Residential School who have enlarged tonsils. I shall be glad if the Department will advise me what action it is desired should be taken. If the Doctor's recommendation is carried out, the cost will probably be $300.00 or more.

Your obedient servant,

Wm Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, September 29, 1927.

Sir:

I have your No. 407-11B of the 22nd instant, enclosing copy of a communication which you received from Mr. Agent Gullion, Saddle Lake, relative to the recommendation of Dr. Decosse that a number of the pupils at the Blue Quills Residential School, who have enlarged tonsils, be operated on. In this connection I beg to say that you may arrange to have the operations carried out in the cases absolutely necessary to the health of the pupils. You should arrange for the best method in dealing with these cases and in having the work performed at the lowest possible cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Sir:-

I beg to enclose herewith, Vouchers No's 2774 and 2775 amounting to $216.45 and $71.22 for drugs supplied to Saddle Lake Agency, for Saddle Lake and Blue Quill's Bands and for Blue Quill's Residential School. INDIAN EDUCATION
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Saddle Lake, Alta.
January 31st, 1929

Sir:

I beg to inform you that Amelia Steinhauer, a pupil at the Blue Quill's Residential school, has had eye trouble for some time. Dr. Decosse examined this girl again yesterday and he recommends that her eyes be tested and that she be fitted with proper glasses. It would be necessary to send her to Edmonton in order to have this done. This girl will be 17 years old in April next.

I should be glad to have your instructions in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
February 8th, 1929.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo regarding Amelia Steinhauer, a pupil at the Blue Quill's Residential School.

This will authorize you to send this girl to Edmonton to be fitted with proper glasses, in accordance with the recommendation of Dr. Decosse.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Sir,

It is observed that Amelia Steinheuer, a pupil of the Blue Quill's Residential School, was recently sent to Edmonton for treatment for an eye condition, and came under the care of Dr. J.G. Young. May I draw your attention to the fact that it has been directed that Indian patients going to Edmonton for treatment of diseases of the eye, ear, nose or throat should be referred to Dr. W. Harold Brown, whose office is in the Tagler Building.

August 4th 1930.

To the Deputy Supt. of Indian Affairs,
Citizens.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter No 95-18-2, of July 22nd, concerning the vaccination of the pupils. I heard here that the vaccination of the Indians was not held on account of smallpox that occurred at this time. So, only the pupils were vaccinated. From this time, 15 pupils have entered into the school who are not yet vaccinated. I will see that, after the re-opening of the school, and after vaccine have been received, those pupils be inoculated.

Truly yours,

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal,
Sacred Heart, P.O.,
Alta.

May 19th, 1931.

Dear Sir:-

In accordance with instructions, I am enclosing herewith, copy of a circular issued by the Department in regard to Tuberculosis and Trachoma cases on the reserves. The letter is self-explanatory.

I have also been reminded that any new pupils who may have entered school during the past year should be vaccinated before the end of the school term. The school year closes June 30th and in the event that I should overlook mentioning the matter, I should be glad if you would call at the Blue Quill's school on your next visit to this reserve and attend to any cases which have not been previously vaccinated.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

J. P. Decosse Esq., M.D.
St. Paul, Alta.
SADDLE LAKE, ALBERTA

June 3rd, 1931.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 93-1 of the 27th ultimo in regard to a report received from Rev'd J. Angin that twenty pupils of the Blue Quill's Residential school had not yet been vaccinated although a list of pupils was supplied last autumn and in reply; I might state that I asked the school for a list of the pupils and received a list containing 65 names, (31 girls and 32 boys) all of whom had been vaccinated as stated in my report of the 23rd August, 1930. Previous to this, I had taken up the matter of vaccination of pupils with Dr. Decosse and he advised me that so far as he was aware, he had vaccinated all of the children in the school and that Sister Breake had a record of this and could furnish the list.

Quite a number of new pupils were taken in during the past year and I am enclosing herewith, copy of letter sent to Dr. J.P. Decosse on the 19th ultimo, requesting him to call at the Blue Quill's school on his next visit to the Saddle Lake reserve, in order to attend to any children who have not been previously vaccinated. Had the Reverend Father Angin mentioned the matter during one of my visits to the school, I could have advised him that it was being kept in mind and that it would be attended to in due course. The Doctor was advised as to regulations in Circular No. 93-1B and I have endeavored to carry out the instructions contained therein. Arrangements have been made to vaccinate all pupils who have not already been attended to and I shall submit a report on this as soon as possible after the end of the school term.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Gullion
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

SADDLE LAKE, ALBERTA.

April 23rd, 1932.

Sir:-

I beg to inform you that the undermentioned medical supplies are required for use at the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school, St. Paul, Alberta;-

Copper Citrate Ointment, Tubes - 36
Wood Applicators ...... 1000

Dr. J.J. Wall found several cases of trachoma at this school during his visit there in February last and Sister Bracke R.N., has been treating them according to his directions. The other pupils are also being treated in accordance with Departmental instructions dealing with prevention.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Gullion
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

July 13th, 1933.

Dear Sir,

The Department is pleased that 45 pupils of the Blue Quill's Indian Residential School have been successfully vaccinated against smallpox. It is, however, a matter for notice that so many pupils of this school should have been unvaccinated. Instructions have been in force for several years, and the new school has been in operation for sufficient time to enable them to be fully put into effect. If smallpox had appeared in this school this number of pupils would have been material for an epidemic.

The instructions place the responsibility for vaccination on the officer in charge of the agency and not on the doctor. Kindly give this matter your attention at the opening of school for the fall term, and see for yourself that all new pupils are vaccinated.

Yours truly,

W. E. Gullion, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Saddle Lake, Alta.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:-

I beg to inform you that all new pupils at the Blue Quill's Residential School were vaccinated during the year. Also Charlie Gladu, Mary Cardinal and Martha Half of this Agency and Eva MacCarthy of the Onion Lake Agency, pupils who are being discharged. I am transmitting herewith a letter from the Reverend Principal in regard to vaccinations.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Gullion,

March 27th 1935

To J.D. Sutherland, Esq.,
Supt of Indian Education,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that the new pupils and also those who will leave the school next June have been vaccinated last Friday.

All have been inoculated unsuccessfully except two girls who have been re-vaccinated: Alice Mayottattik and Victoria Cryer.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal.
SADDLE LAKE, ALBERTA.
April 1st, 1935.

Sir:-

Re Vaccination of Pupils:

I beg to transmit herewith, letter from the Reverend Principal of the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school, reporting on the vaccination of new pupils and those to be discharged in June next.

The Doctor informs me that he vaccinated 16 of the pupils, the vaccinations being mostly unsuccessful.

Your obedient servant,

W.F. Bullion
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
SADDLE LAKE, ALBERTA.

May 29th, 1935.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that when I called at the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school last week, my attention was drawn to the fact that the school did not have a suitable scale for weighing and measuring the pupils from time to time and I was asked if it would be possible to have one furnished for this purpose. Moyer's Health and School Scale No. 325, shown in Moyer's 1932-1933 catalogue would be suitable for this purpose and this is the scale that they had in mind. I believe that in addition to weighing, this has an attachment for measuring height.

Your obedient servant,

W.F. O'Donnell
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, June 11, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, regarding the request that a Health and School scale be supplied for the weighing and measuring of the pupils at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will have no funds to provide this equipment. Could not the school authorities, themselves, provide the cost, if they desire this scale.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

W. E. Gullion, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Saddle Lake,
Alta.

Sir,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, August 5th, 1936.

Dear Sir,

In the annual drug requisition received from the Blue Quill's Indian Residential School, the Principal has asked for, among other things, a scale with measuring rod. This type of scale is seldom if ever supplied to a Residential School owing to the cost, but the Department is willing to expend approximately $15.00 in the purchase of a bathroom scale of the Health-o-meter pattern. It will, therefore, be in order for you to arrange purchase from approved source locally and have the scale sent to the Principal of the school. Kindly quote the date and file number of this letter when submitting an account for payment. A copy of this letter is being sent to Indian Agent Gullion for his information.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

M. Christianson, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.

Blue Quill Indian Res. School,
Saint-Paul, Alta.

August 24th 1936

To the Honourable Harold W. Mac Gill,
Minister of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Honourable Sir,

I herewith inform you that Blue Quills School did not re-open on August 13th through the bad will of Mr. Indian Agent Gullion. This Agent forbade the parents to bring back their children to school on account of whooping cough. In fact, there were some cases of whooping cough on the Saddle-Lake reserve, but only 6 or 7 pupils were sick out of 80; it seems to be ridiculous to maintain home the other 75 pupils. Mr. Gullion told me on August 13th that Dr. Decosse had asked him to run in some of the pupils for 3 weeks, it was false, Mr. Gullion told a lie. Dr. Decosse did not say anything of that; he gave to Gullion a letter dated Aug. 11th or 12th, stating that only the pupils of 5 families should not go to school for a while till they recover. This letter has been read by Mr. Pitre, teacher at Blue Quill School; Mr. Decosse did not hinder the pupils to come back to school; on the contrary, when told by Rev. Father Michel, Missionary at Saddle Lake, that he had visited the school, he was surprised denied it and said that, in his letter to Gullion, nothing of this could be read, and no mistake possible; he was surprised even that the pupils did not come back to school.

If you ask for this letter to Gullion, you will be surprised, Honourable Sir, to see as Gullion is a hypocrite.

When I knew these facts, I had let Pitre phone to Gullion asking him to bring back to school the 75 pupils who were free from disease. Gullion replied he would see again Dr. Decosse, and in fact this latter went through the reserve of Saddle-Lake last Thursday Aug. 20th, but I do not know yet the result of this visit.

I find strange that, where there is some matter relative to the pupils, I am not admitted to discuss this matter with Dr. Decosse and Gullion; they take decision alone. I am rather notify of their decision, an order constituted by the Department cannot harm them, the pupils; this means, I fancy, that I should be admitted into any discussion concerning the pupils. I remember another fact that happened 2 years ago; a girl, Gertrude Cardinal, was sent from school to hospital for eye-disease; she was discharged from hospital and from school both by Dr. Decosse and Gullion, she was home since one week, and I was not notified even of her discharge. This is surprising. I should add, addition to this, any matter concerning the pupils, because I am their guardian, and I do not accept that Dr. Decosse and Gullion can discharge any pupil without my consent, as well as they can not maintain home pupils without my consent. Am I right or wrong?

Now I do not know when the pupils will come back to school; this whooping cough is on the reserve since last fall 1935, and no steps have been taken to stop it. This year, when there is a new break up, I shall have to go to Gullion again before to stop it or to disinfect the barracks of garmattherefore, the disease can spread over and stay for 2 or 3 years.

I cannot understand the conduct of Gullion; for me he is just good for nothing, he does not care about anything, he leaves the Indians quiet, whilst they do not bother himbut as a hypocrite, he can tell lies as many as words.

But this is a big damage made to the school, and I do not know how I can finance the school if the Department cut the grant.
3 weeks or more on account of the absence of the pupils. And,
ask you, Honourable Sir, that the grant be given to Blue Hill
School, as if the children had been present since August 13th.
I say again that the fault is only upon Gullion who should have
obeyed the instructions of Dr. Decosse.

Your obedient Servant,

Rev. Jos. Angin, O.H.I.
Principal.
Ottawa, September 1, 1936.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo, with reference to certain pupils of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School not returning upon the expiry of their leave owing to an outbreak of whooping cough.

Mr. Agent Gullion is being requested to report in connection with this matter. I may say that, if pupils with whooping cough were admitted to a residential school, you would probably have considerable trouble with them all winter.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. Jos. Angin, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Blue Quills Indian Res. School,
Saint Paul, Alta.
Ottawa, September 1, 1936.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, in which he states that Dr. Decosse directed that certain Indian children belonging to five families on the Saddle Lake Reserve be not returned upon the expiry of their leave owing to whooping cough. He further states that, in spite of these directions of the doctor, you have issued instructions for about eighty (80) children of the Saddle Lake Reserve not to return on the date of the opening of the school after the holidays.

Please let the Department have a full report, at once, regarding your action in this matter. If Dr. Decosse gave the instructions mentioned by the Reverend Principal, the Department cannot understand why you kept all the children home.

When replying to this letter, you should forward to the Department the letter which you received from Dr. Decosse regarding whooping cough on the Saddle Lake Reserve.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. E. Gullion, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Saddle Lake, Alta.
Saddle Lake, Alberta,
August 21, 1936.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that owing to an epidemic of whooping cough on the Whitefish Lake reserve, I found it necessary, on the advice of Dr. Eadie of Vilna, to keep the pupils of the Edmonton Residential school and also the Blue Quill's Residential school, at home.

As there was some whooping cough on the Saddle Lake reserve also, I had Dr. Decosse of St. Paul check up the homes on this reserve and he has now also recommended keeping the pupils at home for a time. The principals of both schools were advised accordingly. I might state that the doctors advised holding the children for at least three weeks when another check up would be made as to their fitness to attend school. I might also mention that the Principals of both schools have mentioned the matter of the grant during this period, and asked if this would be paid in a case of this kind.

Your obedient servant,

W. E. Gullion
(Signed)
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
J. P. Beronse,
Physician and Surgeon

St. Paul, Alberta, Aug. 20th. 1936.

The Agent,
Saddle Lake Agency,
Saddle Lake, Alta.

Dear Sir:

Referring to our conversation of August the 9th, when I informed you I had found many children of school age who were suffering from pertussis, and also advised that they should not be sent to school for three or four weeks and further, that all other suspicious cases who were brought to your attention should be investigated before the opening of school and that if too many were reported it would be advisable to keep all the children home until such a time as we were satisfied they were all cured, please note that I have found so many cases since that I am convinced the above action was amply justified.

No doubt many more cases will be reported in the near future.

Yours truly,

J. P. Beronse
September 18th, 1936.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 118-1-13 of the 1st instant in regard to a letter received from the Reverend Principal of the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school in which he evidently endeavoured to make it appear that I had acted contrary to the advice given by Dr. Decosse. As the whooping cough situation was such that I was of the opinion that should the children be sent back to school, serious developments might result, and as this was brought to Father Angin's attention, I am rather surprised at his attitude in the matter. I discussed fully with Dr. Decosse and also with Dr. Fadie, the advisability of keeping the pupils at home for a time and both of the Doctors advised keeping the children home for at least three weeks, this depending on the situation at the end of that period.

The Reverend Principal was advised of this but he evidently considered that he was better informed in the matter than the Doctors who were in attendance as he almost immediately started to urge the Indians to take their children back to school. This, despite the fact that he had been advised as to what was being done and the reason for keeping the pupils out of school for a time. By insisting whenever the Indians called at the school, the Reverend Principal persuaded some of them to take their children to school before they had been passed as fit by the Medical Officers, twenty-three being returned to school in this manner. In doing this, it would appear that Father Angin acted in direct contravention of the health regulations issued by the Department and should his action result in a further outbreak of whooping cough or other serious consequences follow in the case of the children taken into school, he should be prepared to accept full responsibility in the matter.

The situation on the reserves is now improved and the children, after being checked, will be going back to school. As requested, I am enclosing herewith, Dr. Decosse's letter.

Your obedient servant,

W.F. Gullion
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Addressed to:
Doctor J. P. Decosse, St. Paul, Man.
Doctor W. W. Eadie, Vilna, Alta.

October 15th, 1936

Copy to Mr. Gullion, Indian Agent

Dear Doctors Decosse and Eadie:

I have been asked to intervene in the matter of the children from Saddle Lake who are out of Blue Quills and Edmonton Residential Schools on account of whooping cough. The Principals are put out. Perhaps many of them have gone back now, and we have not heard of it.

As for children who have whooping cough, and whom you do not think fit to travel, your judgment must be final. As for the rest, it occurs to me at this distance that they might be better off in the schools than at home. Of course, the Principals will have to consider whether this may involve the spread of the disease to many pupils from other areas, and, if you allow children with whooping cough, or exposed to it, to go back you would be entitled to express your view as to their responsibility. I know also that you and Mr. Gullion have the parents to deal with.

My suggestion is that you and Mr. Gullion should get together, with the Principals of the Schools, if possible, and come to some agreement, or at least compromise.

Yours very truly

E. L. Stone, M. B.
Director of Medical Services
Memorandum:

In writing the Principals you may think it wise to point out that in the last resort, Provincial law and regulations are the final authority in matters of contagious disease, and that the Indian Agent is bound to observe them under the advice of the Doctor.

It may become a matter for compromise between the strict law and the best interest of all concerned, and we have suggested that the Principals, Doctors and Indian Agent try to work out a satisfactory solution together.

E. L. Stone, M. B.
Director of Medical Services
Blue Quills Residential School,
St Paul, Alberta.

October 19th, 1936.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Re: Requisition

Dear Sirs:

On our last requisition of June 19th, 1936, we are short of Gauze. We asked for 2000 yds., we only received 150 yds. Owing to the great amount of dressings being done to those children, we are getting short already. Should we have to get it here it would cost a lot more. Hoping shipment will be made at once.

We have not yet received the Cod Liver Oil. It is time the children should start and take it, as there are quite a number who have been sick and need a tonic. Could you also send some of the Extract of Malt and Cod liver Oil, some of the girls do not digest the pure.

Yours truly,

J. Angin, Principal
Ottawa, October 28th, 1936.

Dear Sir,

The Principal of the Blue Quill's Indian Residential School has written the Department asking to be supplied with 2000 yards of gauze. He claims he asked for this amount in his last requisition. Actually 1000 yards were requested but it was reduced in this office to 150 yards as that is the average quantity usually supplied to Residential Schools. It is also claimed that there is a great amount of dressings being done to the children. It will be appreciated if you will investigate and, if satisfied that the quantity asked for is required, submit a proper requisition approved by the medical attendant.

The Principal should be informed that the cod liver oil substitute known as "Thallatel" was ordered from Vancouver on October 1st, and must be on its way if he has not already received it.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. E. Gullion, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Saddle Lake, Alta.

PJB
J. P. Decorse,
Physician and Surgeon

St. Paul, Alberta, Nov. 4th, 1936.

RX'D.

The Director of Medical Services,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter file No. 118-1-13 and must say that I am surprised to hear that the children had not all returned to school by Oct. 15th.

I completed an inspection of all the children actually on the reserve on Sept. 15th, and advised Mr. Cullion two days afterwards that all the children with a few exceptions could return to school. The latter were cases who had not had pertussis and were coughing at the time, and the parents were advised to keep them home for a week or more and that if the cough ceased, they were to be sent to school, if not, they were to be sent to the Agent who was to advise me as to whether they could be re-examined. As none of these cases reported I assumed that they only had a cold of the ordinary variety and that all had returned to school before Oct. 1st.

The only explanation I can give for this failure on the part of the parents to return the children is that an epidemic of lobar pneumonia existed at that time at the Blue Bull School among the children of other reserves and also among those of Saddle Lake who were admitted before the inspection, and no doubt the parents elected to keep them home until this abated.

Ten Cases of pneumonia, four of which were double, were admitted to the St. Paul Hospital between Sept. 15th and October 14th, with no mortality, fortunately, and in view of this situation, it may have been a wise thing for the parents to do.

Yours truly,

J. P. Decorse

[Signature]

M.D.
Sir:

I beg to submit the following in connection with the pupils of the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school. As mentioned in my letter of the 18th September last, it was necessary, owing to whooping cough on the Saddle Lake and Whitefish Lake reserves, to keep the children home. This action was taken after the situation had been fully discussed with the Medical Officer. As the situation was clearing up toward the end of the month, arrangements were made to have all of the children who were fit, return to the schools on the 1st October. A few were kept at home at that time and the last group, ten in number, were sent back to the Edmonton Residential school on the 27th.

In the meantime however, there appeared to be an epidemic of pneumonia at the Blue Quill's Residential school as there were ten cases of pneumonia taken to the hospital from the school between the 15th September and the 14th October four of these cases being double pneumonia. As those of the children kept home after the 1st October became fit and parents directed to take their children to school, they hesitated in some cases owing to fear that their children might contract pneumonia. In some cases their children were just recovering from whooping cough. Fortunately, so far, there have been no deaths there from this disease.

I might say that none of the parents refused definitely to take their children back to school when directed that they should do so. They stated in most cases that owing to hearing of so many pneumonia cases at the school, they did not wish to take the risk of losing their children and that they would rather keep them for a short time or until such time as the pneumonia situation cleared up to some extent. Compulsion might have been resorted to, to have the children taken in immediately after they were considered fit. On the other hand, if this action had been taken and pneumonia had caused the death of a pupil after being taken in, a very disagreeable situation would have been created.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
When I was at Whitefish Lake reserve on the 20th October, I advised the Indians there that any pupils of the schools, Edmonton Residential and Blue Quill's, who were still out, should be returned to the schools to which they belonged. There did not seem to be any objection to this. However, upon making enquiries lately, I was informed that they had expected that the motor truck from the school would be sent up for the few children there. I shall make enquiries and if this was not done, some arrangement will be made to have any absentee brought in. The truck could have been sent up from the Blue Quill's school for the children at Whitefish Lake, and this would no doubt have speeded up the return of some of the children as some of the Indians do not own horses.

Checking up at Beaver Lake reserve on the 6th October, I found that some of the children there had whooping cough. This had just started and the parents were advised that the children would be required at the Blue Quill's school in about three or four weeks time. There are seven pupils there. These will now be brought in if fit.

The situation in connection with the schools this year was unavoidable and although the schools may have lost a little in the way of grants, the matter throughout has been dealt with in a manner considered in the best interests of everybody concerned.

In conclusion, I would like to add that a more reasonable attitude by the Principal in unavoidable issues and the co-operation of the schools in recruiting and getting children back to school, would be very much appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

W.E.Gullion
Indian Agent.
Saddle Lake, Alta., Nov. 10, 1936.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my report for the month of October 1936.

HEALTH

The general health of the Indians has been fair. There were a number of cases of pneumonia amongst the school children at Blue Quill's residential school. Whooping Couch cases were all better and the remaining school children were returned to school. Nurse Fisk has been on the Whitefish and Saddle Lake reserves during the month and reports no sickness of a serious nature.

W. E. Gullion.
Indian Agent.

Del Carter requisites
Blue Quills Indian Residential School,
Sacred Heart, P.O., Alta., Jan. 29th, 1931.

Honourable Sir:

With regards the requisition for the farm, I have asked for six working horses; at present there are here five horses, of which two are 18 years old. As to milking cows, I have applied for 10; the 10 cows here at the present are also getting old and soon will have to be slaughtered for beef.

You will notice that there is also a list for the shop, mostly of tools required for repairs to house or of farm equipment; and this will prove a great economy to the institution as our engineer can thereby attend to any urgent and necessary repairs.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. Jos. Angin.
Principal.
February 14, 1937.

Memorandum:

In a few weeks, it will be necessary to supplement the live stock and agricultural machinery and to purchase some workshop tools for the new Blue Quills Indian Residential School. I should be pleased if you would indicate sources of supply for the following:

(a) Work horses.
(b) Milch cows.
(c) Agricultural implements.
(d) Blacksmith and work shop tools.

Russell T. Harris

Supt. of Indian Education
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Ottawa, April 14, 1931.

Mr. Ferrier,

With reference to your memorandum of February 14, last, regarding additional livestock and agricultural implements for the new Blue Quills Indian residential school near St. Paul, Alta., kindly note that purchases may be made from the following firms:

Horses - Harold Welsh,
St. Paul, Alta.

Cattle & Implements - Charles Gauvreau,
St. Paul, Alta.

D. S. G. I. A.
THE RENFREW MACHINERY COMPANY LTD.

Renfrew

HEAD OFFICE AND WORKS
RENFREW ONT.
BRANCH OFFICES
SUSSENBURG MONTREAL QUE REGINA SASK MILWAUKEE U.S.A.

RENFREW - ONTARIO

June 9th, 1931.

The Purchasing Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Canada.

Dear Sir:

We are advised that it is your intention to purchase in the early future an 800 lb. Electric Cream Separator for your new Indian Industrial School at St. Paul, Alta., and we are wondering if we may ask you to let us figure in this matter. May we also at the outset point out that we are an entirely Canadian company, operating on Canadian capital and employing Canadian workmen making a splendid standard line of cream separators and we certainly would be very pleased indeed if you would give us an opportunity to figure on this particular machine you are purchasing in the near future.

Yours very truly,

H. A. Jordan,
Managing-Director,

[Signature]

PLEASE ADDRESS ALL BUSINESS COMMUNICATIONS TO THE COMPANY
Ottawa, June 16, 1931.

Gentlemen:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, requesting an opportunity to quote on an 800 Lb. electric cream separator for use at the new Indian residential school at St. Paul, Alta.

In reply I have to say that if this type of equipment is required your letter will not be overlooked.

Yours truly,

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

The Renfrew Machinery Co. Ltd.,
Renfrew,
Ont.
August 12, 1931.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD

With reference to your memorandum of yesterday's date, concerning supplying the Blue Quills Indian Residential School with horses, cattle and machinery, I may say that, during the next few months, a few purchases will have to be made. On April 10th, last, you gave me a memorandum concerning sources of supply for live stock and implements. If there are any others that you wish to have quoted, please let me know.

Concerning the painting of the floors at the new school, I may say it is not the intention to proceed with this work this year.

A. S. Williams,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Ottawa, August 31, 1931.

Mr. Fernier,

Mr. Buskard wishes to have the following information this afternoon for sure:

How many head of horses and cattle will be required for the Blue Quills school and the approximate price to be paid, also a list of the machinery required.

Acting D. S. G. I. A.
August 31, 1931.

Memorandum:

Pursuant to telephone conversation this afternoon, I have to inform you that horses, cattle and agricultural machinery will be purchased for the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, in the electoral district of Athabasca, from time to time, during the next few months, as required. The original requisition from the Reverend Principal indicated that six horses, ten cows and the following agricultural machinery would be required:

- Breaking plough,
- Mower,
- Gang plough,
- Rake,
- Disc,
- Wagon,
- Harrow,
- Bob sleigh,
- Drill.

I may say it is not the intention to purchase any of this equipment until the Reverend Principal writes that particular stock or machinery is then required. The current prices for the locality of St. Paul, Alberta, will be paid when purchase is made. It is possible that a team or two of horses, the ten cows, a harrow, wagon and bob sleigh will be required during the next few months and that the rest of the equipment and stock will be needed in the spring.

A. S. Williams,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Feb.16th 1932

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

With reference to your letter No 118-1-14, of Feb. 16th,
relative to the live stock to be supplied to the Blue Quills
School, I may say that Mr Charles Gaspereau will be asked to
find it and to state price.

As to the veterinary surgeon, I must say that Doctor
Biscouette, who was injured in the car crash where the Hon.
Buckley found death, is now unable to work, and then there is
still not another veterinary surgeon at St-Paul.

Truly yours,

Rev. Jos. Anglin,
Principal.
To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

In reference with your letter No 118-1-14, of Feb. 4th, relative to the machines to be supplied to the Blue Quills School, I may say that, according to your letter, I have asked, 5 weeks ago, for the prices of these, to Mr Charles Gauvreau of St-Paul, but have not got any reply. It is possible that Mr Gauvreau have written to the Department directly.

Considering however that the spring is coming soon and that the agricultural implements will be needed within one month, I have taken the liberty to ask for prices to the principal firms of machinery in St-Paul that have always repairs in hand in stock and I submit below their prices for your information:

| Massey-Harris | Mc Cormick-Deering |
|---------------|--------------------|
| 16" Breaking plow | $92.00 | $93.00 |
| 16" Disc | $92.00 | $88.75 |
| Spring tooth harrow | $90.00 | $90.25 |
| 20 ft Drill | $299.00 | $299.00 |
| Bob-sleigh with double-box | $113.50 | $108.00 |

For freight from Edmonton to St-Paul $27.44

The Massey-Harris firm gives a 7% discount on Machinery, and 5% on sleigh, so that the amount totals to $575.65

The Mc Cormick-Deering firm gives a 10% discount on all, so that the amount totals to $566.99.

I know that Mr Gauvreau has yet some machines from Lacrosse Flow works, of Racine, Wisc. I would be very obliged to the Department not to furnish these same machines to the school, as it takes 3 weeks before getting repairs from Racine, Wisc.

Truly yours,

Rev. Jos. Ancin,
Principal.
To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

In reply to your letter No 118-1-14, of Feb. 4th, concerning the livestock to be supplied to the Blue Quills School, I must say that Mr. Charles Gauvreau of St-Paul, has submitted no price till now.

Then I can state for your information that the farmers here around the school could supply 10 good cows, fresh, young, healthy for the price of $50.00 per head, and below. Those cows are not Shorthorn, but Ayrshires mixed up with pure Shorthorn.

As to one bull, I have no reference to submit now.

Truly yours,

Rev. Jos. Aurin,
Principal.
Ottawa, July 5, 1932.

Sir,

I have your letter No 118-1-14, of July 5th, stating you can help the Blue Quills School in supplying milk cows and agricultural implements. I thank you for your kindness and must say that 10 cows and one bull, all dairy Shorthorn, would be very necessary at the present. We have only 7 cows now and this number is very insufficient.

As to the agricultural implements, I can say that these asked for last spring are yet wanted, viz:

- 1 16" brush breaker/which is breaking-plow
- 1 16-run disk
- 1 spring tooth harrow with truck
- √1 20-run drill
- 1 bob-sleigh with double-box.

As the funds are limited, you will grant according to your funds, but I would be pleased to get all these supplies, if possible.

Yours truly,

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal.

August 26th 1932.

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have already written to you about the fencing of the playgrounds for the pupils, and I must again draw your attention on this fact that the pupils being come back, it is difficult to watch over them. The playgrounds should be fenced the soonest possible, chiefly when it is time yet to make fence; pretty soon, it will be too cold to have the playgrounds fenced.

The pump is working very badly and I fear it breaks sometime. Mr. Indian Agent Gullion has been advised two months ago and I asked at this time that the pump be taken off and fixed again. Would it be possible that the man who has settled down this pump come again to see about it?

Our wheat is already cut and pretty soon it will be the turn of the oats to be cut, and after wards the threshing will take place. I get you remember that we have no granary and no other place to put our crop. Therefore a granary should be built very soon. I hope you will take steps in this connection.

Yours truly,

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal.
Ottawa, September 1st, 1932.

Sir,

The Principal of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School St. Paul, Alta., has requested that the following agricultural implements, fencing and cattle be supplied:

Agricultural Implements:
- 1 - 16" Breaking Plough
- 1 - 16" Disc
- 1 - Spring tooth harrow
- 1 - 20 R Drill
- 1 - Bob sleigh with double box

Fencing:
- 340 - Cedar fence posts, 7 ft. high
- 190 - Rods woven fencing, 48 in. high
- 50 - lbs. Staples, 1/2" long
- 3 - Spools barb wire, 4 points
- 2 - Plain farm gates; steel wire, 14 ft. long, 48 in. high

Milch Cows:
- 10 - Grade shorthorn milch cows
- 1 - Shorthorn bull

The Department will be able to provide a small amount at the present time to purchase the above equipment, and I would request that you report what items of the above are most urgent. With regard to the cows, the principal states that they have 7 cows at the school at present. Would it be necessary to supply 10 more at this time?

I am uncertain what arrangements could be made with Charles Gauvreau, of St. Paul, for supplying the cows and farm implements and the cost. Please state, also, whether you could arrange for the purchase of any equipment authorized, including the milch cows and bull, or whether you would recommend that this be placed in the hands of Mr. Agent Guillion. I should be pleased if you would give an approximate estimate of the cost of supplying the equipment, live stock, etc., which you recommend at the present time.

The Principal is anxious to obtain the fencing material as early as possible and, in order to prevent delay, you may arrange for the purchase from indicated sources of supply of the quantity of fencing material, as mentioned above. Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost and attach same to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department for payment.

I shall be pleased to have your recommendation regarding the agricultural implements and milch cows.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 1st instant in connection with the agricultural implements, fencing, and cattle asked for by the Blue Quills Indian Residential School at St. Paul. You have my report on this school dated the 24th ultimo, and you will note that I have stated that the following agricultural implements will be required:

- 1 - 16" Breaking Plow
- 1 - 16" Disk
- 1 - 20-run Drill
- 1 - set spring toothed Harrows
- 1 - Bob sleight with box - Required this fall.

The fencing is for the playgrounds, and when I was there the Principal estimated the cost at $250. These grounds should, of course, be fenced, but there is no reason why this cannot be held over until spring, if necessary. In any event, I am not very much in favour of fencing playgrounds with woven wire as it soon gets out of shape from the boys standing on it, &c. I think plain wire with a rail on top of the fence would be more suitable.

With reference to the milch cows and bull: No doubt this school requires additional cows as they only have seven at the present time, but if say five additional cows were supplied this fall, I think that would be sufficient to meet the requirements of the school at least until spring. The bull of course is not required until spring, and can be purchased at the Edmonton bull sale which is held about the 1st of April. The approximate cost of good milch cows would be between $50 and $60.

Therefore,......

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Therefore, all that would be absolutely necessary to supply at the present time would be the Bob-sleigh and box at a cost of about $90 and five cows at an approximate cost of $300. I note that the Department state arrangements could be made with Chas. Gauvreau for supplying cows and farm implements, and they desire to know the cost of same: I am of the opinion that this man is not a dealer in any of the lines mentioned. The Bob-sleigh and box could be bought in the usual manner and delivered through an implement dealer at St. Paul, and Mr. Gullion, the Agent, is quite capable of purchasing the cows, from the farmers in that district. Of course if the Department wish to place the purchasing of these implements, &c., in the hands of Mr. Gauvreau, I will see that this is done.

I might also refer to the granary which was mentioned in my recent report on this school: This is something that is required by the school this fall, if there is any means whatever of financing it.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christiansen,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.
September 17, 1932.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

It is necessary at the present time to purchase five cows and one set of bob sleighs, with box, for the new Blue Quills Indian Residential School at St. Paul, Alta. In April, 1931, you directed that, when cattle and farm machinery were being supplied, the purchase be made from Charles Gauvreau, St. Paul, Alta.

Mr. Inspector Christianson, Calgary, Alta., states he is of opinion that this man is not a dealer in any of the lines mentioned. He recommends that Mr. Gullion, the local Agent, arrange for the purchase of the cows from farmers in that district and that the bob sleighs and box be bought in the usual manner and delivered through an implement dealer in St. Paul. I should be pleased to have your directions regarding the purchase of the above.

It will also be necessary next Spring to purchase a breaking plow, disc, drill and set of spring tooth harrows, also a bull and five cows. I shall be pleased to have your instructions regarding the above purchases.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Ottawa, September 22, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, in connection with the agricultural implements, fencing and cattle for the Blue Quills Indian Residential School at St. Paul, Alta. It is noted that the only farm equipment required at the present time is one bob sleigh, with box, and I would request that you arrange for the purchase, from a firm on the list handling these supplies, and have same delivered at the school when considered timely. Please obtain an account, in triplicate, covering the cost, which you should certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

Regarding the fencing of the playgrounds, as our funds this year are limited, this work can be held over until next Spring. This matter may be brought to the attention of the Department at that time and full details should be given regarding materials and cost.

With reference to the purchase of milch cows, I have to say that the Department is prepared at the present time to supply the school with five grade milch cows. It is considered that a good type of grade cows would be satisfactory. They should be young and giving milk, or to freshen early in the new year.

You may arrange with Mr. Agent Gullion, if you are assured he is a good judge of cattle, to make the purchase. He should give Mr. Charles Gauvreau, St. Paul, an opportunity to supply the cows, but if Mr. Gauvreau is unable to do so, the Agent may make the purchase locally. It would be advisable that he secure the aid of a Government Livestock Man, if one is in the district, in selecting the cows. All cows should be free from tuberculosis and should be of good milking strain. It is noted you are of opinion that the cost of good milch cows would be between $50 and $60 each. It is hoped that they can be obtained at a price not exceeding this figure. After the Agent has completed the purchase, he should forward for payment accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, in favour of the parties from whom the cows are purchased.

The question of supplying a further number of cows, additional agricultural implements and fencing material will receive consideration this coming Spring.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

M. Christianson, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.
Ottawa, September 23rd, 1932.

Sir,

The Principal of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School has forwarded to the Department the enclosed list of equipment which he desires supplied.

Owing to lack of funds, it will not be possible to authorize any further expenditure this year than was mentioned in official letter of the 22nd instant. You will note from the last paragraph of that letter that the question of supplying a further number of cows, additional agricultural implements and fencing material will receive consideration next spring although, at the present time, the Department is unable to state what funds, if any, will be available for this purpose.

You might, however, give careful consideration to the list enclosed with this letter and, at your convenience, you should report to the Department what articles on the list you consider are absolutely necessary. When replying, the list should be returned.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

M. Christianson, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.

Sir:

I beg to forward herewith Saddle Lake Voucher No. 3594 in favour of Mr. A. S. Spence of St. Paul, for $285 for five cows purchased for the Blue Quikks School.

I received a letter from the Reverend Principal this morning, and he informed me that he is well satisfied with the cows. One has just freshened and is giving a good quantity of milk; one is due to freshen within a week or ten days; another will freshen towards the end of the month and the other two are due to freshen sometime in January. The cows are dual purpose Shorthorns.

This expenditure was authorized by Department letter No. 118-1-14 of September 22nd last. I would recommend the payment of this voucher.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

January 9, 1933

MEMORANDUM

DR. MCGILL

With reference to memorandum (Mr. Williams') of September 17, 1932, re the purchase of five cows for the new Blue Quills Indian Residential School at St. Paul, Alta.

The Minister's instructions in this connection were - in part - "Mr. Guayrath to be given an opportunity to supply cattle requirements." It is understood, however, that the purchase was made from Mr. A.S. Spence, of St. Paul.

Will you please furnish the Minister with a report in this matter.

Private Secretary.
January 10th, 1932.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Buskard -

I have to refer to your memorandum of the 9th January regarding the purchase of five cows for the Blue Quills Residential School at St. Paul, Alberta. In our memorandum of September 17th referred to by you, direction was requested regarding the purchase of the cows by Mr. Gullion, the Indian agent, from farmers in the district, as Inspector Christianson had stated that Mr. Gauvreau was not a dealer in any of the lines mentioned. This action was approved by the Minister provided Mr. Gullion was considered to be a good judge of cattle and the suggestion was made that he secure the aid of a Government line stockman if one were in the district. It was further stated that Mr. Gauvreau should be given an opportunity to supply the cattle required.

On this ruling, Inspector Christianson was informed that if he considered agent Gullion a good judge of cattle, the agent might be authorized to make the purchase. He was to be instructed that Mr. Gauvreau should be given an opportunity to supply the cows but if he was unable to do so the agent might make the purchase locally. He was to be further instructed in regard to securing the services of a Government stockman in selecting the cows.

Although no further correspondence took place, it is assumed that the agent acted on these instructions and being unable to secure the cattle from Mr. Gauvreau he made purchase from A. S. Pence. The voucher submitted for payment in this connection bears the following words: "Authority: Inspector Christianson's letters No. 407-11A of Sept. 26th and Nov. 23rd, 1932."

I trust this explanation is satisfactory.

Sir,

I beg to bring to your attention that the Department authorized me to purchase a set of Bob-Sleighs and a Box for the Blue Quill School, in the Saddle Lake Agency, in their letter 118-1-14, of September 22nd.

I received quotations on the Bob-Sleigh and Box, and the John Deere Plow Company were the lowest tender, and the Sleigh and Box was delivered through their Agent at St. Paul. It then developed that what the Principal wanted was a Grain Tank and not a Wagon Box. He also wanted a set of trees and yoke. Trees and yoke are not a part of a bob-sleigh, but rather than have a lot of fuss over nothing I had the wagon box changed for the Grain Tank, and the trees and yoke furnished.

The extra cost in this connection, over and above the Wagon Box is $30.95. Therefore a voucher is herewith attached for $70.35 and abstract for tenders is also attached for same, and another voucher attached for the extra $30.95.

I hope this meets with the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Alberta Inspectorate

March 29th, 1933.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant in regard to the purchase last year of five cows for the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school. In reply, I wish to submit the following report:

In Mr. Inspector Christianson's letter No. 407-11A of the 26th September, 1932, I received instructions in part as follows: "As to the purchase of additional milk cows, you are hereby authorized to purchase five grade milk cows for the school of a good milk type. You should see the Principal and ascertain from him what would be the most suitable time for the cows to freshen. When the Department wrote to me in this connection I advised them that the cows could be purchased at a price of from $50. to $60. and this amount should not be exceeded. I think we should get exceptionally good cows for even $50. You are aware of the market price at the present time, and I would consider that real good cows can be bought for this amount. In making the purchase you are to give Mr. O'Meara an opportunity to supply the five cows that are required, but if he is unable to do so, you may purchase them locally wherever you can find suitable ones.

The cows were also to be T.B. tested. On the 13th October, I interviewed Mr. O'Meara in regard to supplying the five cows required. I advised him as to the kind and type of cows required and also informed him that he should endeavor to see the Reverend Principal of the Blue Quill's school before getting any cows. In my report for the month of October, I mentioned that the cows had not yet been delivered. By letter dated November 23rd, 1932,

Harold W. McGill Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Mr. Inspector Christianson advised me that the matter had already been too long delayed and instructed me to get in touch with the Principal immediately and buy five cows that were suitable to him. I received Mr. Christianson's letter on the 29th November and on the following day, I called at the school and the cows was one of the subjects discussed with Rev. Father Anzin. He informed me that he wished to have at least two cows fresh, the others to freshen before Spring. I was in St. Paul but did not see Mr. Guivray on that date. I however met Mr. Walter Allen from North of St. Paul and he mentioned that Mr. Guivray had told him that a number of cows were needed for the school. I advised Mr. Allen that I would look over his cattle as soon as possible. The day following, December 1st, I drove out to Mr. Allen's and looked over his herd. While some of his cattle were fairly smooth, they were not of the larger type and with the exception of one very poor heifer, none of the cows that I looked over had freshened. He had three heifers, I believe raising three years, that I considered the most promising. His cows, I understand, were not freshening until Spring. I advised Mr. Allen that five cows were required for the school and that I wished to get cows that Mr. Guivray suitable to the Principal. I also told Mr. Allen that I could advise the Principal in regard to his (Mr. Allen's) cattle and that if the Principal considered that they might be suitable, he might drive over and look at them. The Principal, however, did not want any untried milk cows or any that were not going to freshen during the Winter.

As Mr. Guivray was apparently making no further efforts to secure the cows, I did not again approach him in connection with the matter and proceeded to carry out Mr. Christianson's instructions. On making enquiries in St. Paul, I was advised by Mr. H.A. Welsh and others to get in touch with Mr. A.S. Spence, whom it was considered was the most familiar with the stock in the district. On the 3rd December, I got in touch with Mr. Spence and advised him of the kind and type of cows required. The cows were accordingly delivered at the school on the 16th December. I called at the school with Mr. Spence on Saturday the 17th and checked up on the animals with him. The cows supplied were large and of a very good type. One cow had just freshened, one was to freshen at once and another one within ten days, the other two being due to come in a little later. The Reverend Principal informed me that he was very well satisfied with the cows. The cows were purchased with the understanding that they would pass the T.B. test and Mr. Spence is having them tested. Taking the time...
time spent in looking for suitable cows, trucking, etc., into consideration, I was of the opinion that for the type supplied, the cows were reasonably priced.

It was represented to the Department that the cows were purchased at an amount which was $75.00 more than the price quoted by Mr. Allen. The cows furnished were of course worth the difference or I should not have made the purchase. There were cattle in the district that could have been bought at prices even lower than Mr. Allen's but there is the difference between suitable and unsuitable animals to be taken into consideration.

I fail to see any reason why Mr. Gauvreau should feel aggrieved as he was given an opportunity and I think plenty of time, to procure the cows. In this connection, I might mention that when in St. Paul on the 26th January last, Mr. A.J. Lebel asked me to call at his office. I did so and he then brought up the matter of the cows stating that Mr. Gauvreau had requested him to write Ottawa and ask for an investigation in the matter of the purchase. Mr. Lebel thought that it might be advisable to see Mr. Gauvreau and Mr. Allen regarding this but after considering the matter, I came to the conclusion that it would be very poor policy to go about explaining my action in a matter in which I considered I was right and in accordance with instructions from my superior officer. In discussing this with Mr. Lebel, I explained the situation and he was apparently satisfied. There was absolutely nothing for which I considered I should place myself on the defensive and I felt that I had no occasion to adopt that attitude.

I have gone into this at some length in an endeavor to make the situation clear and in conclusion, would say that I regret very much any annoyance the purchase of the cows may have caused.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
W.E. Sullivan
Indian Agent.
April 20, 1933.

Memorandum:

Mr. Buckard,

I wish to refer to your memorandum of the 14th ultimo, regarding the purchase of five cows by Mr. E. Gullion, Indian Agent, Redville Lake, Alberta. From Mr. A. S. Spence, for the Blue Quill Indian Residential School, without the application of the T.B. test to the animals and at $75 over the quotation of Mr. Walter Allen of St. Paul. A report regarding the purchase has been received from Mr. Gullion, from which I quote as follows:

"I received instructions from Mr. Inspector Christianson to arrange for the purchase of five grade milk cows of a good milk type and to give Mr. Gouvreau an opportunity to supply the cows but that, if he was unable to do so, to purchase them locally wherever suitable ones could be obtained - the cows to be T.B. tested. On October 13th I interviewed Mr. Gouvreau, advising him of the type of cows required. On the 25th of November, Mr. Gouvreau was apparently making no effort to secure the cows. I did not again approach him in connection with the matter. I met Mr. Walter Allen and inspected his herd. While some of his cattle were fairly smooth, they were not of the larger type and, with the exception of one very poor cow, none of the cows had freshened. He had three heifers rising three years, which I considered the most promising. I advised him then that five cows were required for the school that would prove suitable to the Principal. The Principal did not want any untried milk cows or any that were not going to freshen during the winter. On making enquiries, I was advised to get in touch with Mr. A. S. Spence, who, it was considered, was most familiar with the stock in the district. I got in touch with Mr. Spence, advising him of the kind and type required and the cows were delivered at the school on the 16th of December. I called at the school and checked up the animals with him. The cows supplied were large and of a very good type. One cow had just freshened and one was to freshen at once and another within 10 days, the other two within a few weeks in a little later. The Principal informed me he was well satisfied. The cows were purchased with the understanding that they would pass the T.B. test and Mr.

- Spence
Spence is having them tested.

"While it is represented that the cows were purchased at a cost of $75 more than the price quoted by Mr. Allen, I would point out that they were worth the difference, and I would not have made the purchase. There were cattle in the district that could have been bought at prices even lower than Mr. Allen's, but there is the difference between suitable and unsuitable animals to be taken into consideration."

In concluding his letter, Mr. Gullion states:

"I fail to see any reason why Mr. Gauvreau should feel aggrieved as he was given an opportunity and I think, plenty of time, to procure the cows. In this connection, I might mention that when in St. Paul on the 26th January, last, Mr. J. U. Lebel asked me to call at his office. I did so and he then brought up the matter of the cows, stating that Mr. Gauvreau had refused like to write others and ask for an investigation in the matter of the purchase. Mr. Lebel thought that it might be advisable to see Mr. Gauvreau and Mr. Allen regarding this, but, after considering the matter, I came to the conclusion that it would be very poor policy to go about explaining my action in a matter in which I considered I was right and in accordance with instructions. After considerable discussion and discussing this with Mr. Lebel, I explained the situation and he was apparently satisfied. There was absolutely nothing for which I considered I should place myself on the defensive and I felt that I had no occasion to adopt that attitude."

I may add that Mr. Spence, from whom the cattle were purchased, has been paid at the rate of $60 each for two cows and $55 each for three cows - a total of $255.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Christianson:

In my estimate to the Department last year I asked for 6 work horses and 2 double harnesses that we may prepare our land for the seeding. These horses and harnesses will be absolutely needed soon next spring, and I would be satisfied if you could ask the Department that horses and harnesses be supplied to the school during April.

We have 130 acres to seed this year, but out of these 130 acres 100 have to be ploughed very carefully, as it will be the first ploughing since the land was broken. Just now I have only 6 horses for this work and it is completely insufficient. I hope that you will obtain from the Department horses and harnesses. I suppose that now you enjoy a very good health.

Yours truly,

"JOS. ANGIN O. M. I."
Principal.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your 407-11A of the 12th instant, enclosing letter from the Principal of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, in which he requests the Department to purchase six work horses and two sets of harness.

Please let me have a definite recommendation with regard to the necessity of supplying the horses and harness requested by the Principal.

In the event of your recommending the purchase, please give an estimate of the cost of the horses and state where they can be secured. On receipt of this information, the Department will be in a position to decide if funds can be provided.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

M. Christianson, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Calgary, Alta.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department's letter No. 115-1-14 of the 18th instant in connection with the 6 horses and 2 sets of harness asked for by the Principal of Blue Quills Indian Residential School in the Saddle Lake Agency. In reply would state that to carry out the programme of the school re farming operations, the Principal actually requires the six horses and two sets of harness. I find that horses up in that country are worth about $90.00 each. They can be purchased from farmers in the vicinity as no doubt most good farmers would be glad to sell a team of horses as cash is very scarce around St. Paul at the present time. I think it would be safe, if the horses were authorized, to let Mr. Gullion buy them, as I noticed the last time I was around with him that he was a fairly good judge of live stock. I would not have the time to go up there just now. The roads are impassible and I am very busy.

The harness could be purchased from the Great West Saddlery Company here and shipped from their Edmonton branch. Good harness can be bought for about $35.00 per set.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, April 6, 1934.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your 407-11A of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the horses and harness requested by the Principal of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

The necessary funds for the purchase of the above have been provided in our Appropriation for the fiscal year 1934-35, and you may therefore authorize Mr. Gullion to purchase six horses, suitable for the Blue Quills School. It is noted, from your letter, that the horses can be secured at a cost not exceeding $80 each.

You may arrange for the purchase of two sets of harness from the Great West Saddlery Company, at a cost of $85.00 a set.

Enclosed is E. R. No. 2017 as your authority for the purchase of the above.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

M. Christianson, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.
Sir:

I beg to advise you that a voucher is going forward today for the 6 horses purchased for Blue Quills school, also for the harness. The Principal advised me that he has received the horses and harness and wishes me to extend his thanks to the Department for furnishing him with this outfit. The horses are very fit being all young horses weighing from 1400 to 1500 pounds and before taking them over, I advised the Agent to be sure that the Principal was satisfied with the purchase, which he did. You will note that a saving of $15.00 has been made on the six horses.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

This Branch would like to have an inspection of the herd at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, St. Paul, Alberta. I trust you will find it possible to have one of your inspectors visit this school and test the cattle.

Ottawa, December 18, 1941

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your communication under date of December 15th, file 118-1-14, in which you request that arrangements be made for the inspection of the herd of cattle at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, St. Paul, Alberta, by a veterinary inspector of this Division.

In this connection I presume that you are referring to the tuberculin testing of the herd and, if so, it will be necessary for you to first place the herd under one of this Department's policies for the eradication of bovine tuberculosis. The only policy which would be open to you is the supervised herd plan and, if you desire to take advantage of this plan, it will be necessary for you to have the party responsible for the herd fill in and sign the enclosed agreement forms and return one of them to this office. The duplicate copy should be retained by the party signing the agreement.

I would point out that no compensation is paid for any cattle which react to a test conducted under the supervised herd plan, but the Institution will receive whatever proceeds there may be from any carcasses which are passed as fit for human consumption. No charge is made for the services of our inspectors, but everything possible is done to eradicate tuberculosis from the herd and to maintain it free from this disease.
R. A. H. -:2:-

I would particularly point out that the responsible person with whom this Department will deal should sign the agreement forms.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Veterinary Director General.

Enclos.
OH/LL

2nd June 1944.

Dear Mr. Morris, (Wherever you may be)

Have been thinking about you all week the weather if anything here has been worse than last week, so we had some luck with the weather anyhow.

I quote from my monthly report as follows:

"A very enjoyable and instructive visit was received from Mr. J.E. Morris from May 15th to May 26th, having an official visit to the Agency, and go over the ground with you is like a refresher course, while we had bad weather which threw some of plans out of gear, I think Mr. Morris saw a very good cross section of the Agency. I thoroughly enjoyed his visit and help and information I received from him, and I can also say this for the rest of the staff. I only hope he may be able to visit this Agency again, and that other officials may also come. I hope I have success with some of his projects he is anxious to start and I think I see some action in the making already."

And I do mean just that Mr. Morris.

I visited the Blue Quill's School last Wednesday night and Father Letour is ready to go on some goats. Please advise me how to procure same and thru what channels. His brother from Duck Lake was there and he is having good luck with goats so Father Principal at Blue Quill's would like to get started and I think it is an ideal place to start. I regret I did not ask you for instructions how to procure goats when you visited here. Not only goats I have thoughts of endless questions I could have discussed with you that I passed up.

Trust the weather is better with you and that your trip is going O.K. Best of Luck.

With kindest regards from Mrs. Pugh & self.

Yours truly,

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Mr. Hoey it is considered that this may be an opportunity to get goats started in the Saddle Lake Agency. If a male goat is being sent to Father Forcade from Spanish another one could be shipped to the Blue Quill's school at the same time.

Leask, Sask. June 15th.

Dear Mr Pugh,

Re.-Goats for Blue Quill's School

Your very welcome letter of June 2nd. finally caught up to me. I discussed the purchase of goats with Indian Agent Ostrander of Battleford and he is going to obtain six or seven female grade goats in that district. In fact while I was there we bought two milking mannies. He feels certain that others can be secured. You are requested to communicate with him and give him shipping instructions. Mr Ostrander suggested that the goats be delivered to a railway point immediately south of your location and have the school truck pick them up rather than send them all the way to Edmonton and then back out to St Paul. Note the shortest and quickest route should be arranged as the mannies are milking.

Please discuss with Father Letour the purchase and care of these goats and advise him that the Department is supplying them on the understanding that the senior girls and boys will be given instructions on their care. It should also be understood that an equal number of females will be given to some responsible Indians as the herd increases.

Regarding a male goat for this herd I am suggesting that a Pure Breed Saanen be sent from the Spanish Herd. It is thought this could be arranged as we are shipping one from this herd to Father Forcade at Grouard, Sask. If it impossible to ship a male from Ontario you will be advised by Ottawa.

J. E. Morris
Welfare Branch
Department of Agriculture  
Production Service  
Health of Animals Division
