EXTRACT FROM MR. MORRIS'S REPORT ON THE DUCK LAKE AGENCY -

BEARDY'S RESERVE

The goats at this school are doing very nicely. They are milked regularly and the milk is used in the school. The Sister in charge of the dairy has successfully made butter from the milk and a sample and instructions are being sent to Ottawa for inspection. Father Latour has distributed ten (10) young female goats to Indians on the Beardy's Reserve. He visits this Reserve regularly and will give the goats constant supervision.

Note: Father Latour requested that, if possible, a pure bred Saanen male be sent to him from Spanish. Mr. Roberts - kindly endeavour to obtain one for the Duck Lake School. Note: The understanding with Father Primeau is that all male goats of the Saanen herd at Spanish will be made available for our service at a cost of $80.00 each, crated f.o.b. Spanish. I have already asked that a Saanen male be sent to the Grouard and Blue Quills Schools. When these shipments are being made another one could be included for Duck Lake.

J. E. Morris,
Welfare Division
Ottawa, July 8th, 1944.

G. P. Schmidt, Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies,
CALGARY, ALTA.

Requests have recently been received for Pure Breed Male Guanaco Goats for the Duck Lake and Blue Quills Schools, and I would appreciate hearing from you regarding the possibility of obtaining two suitable animals somewhere in B.C.

R. A. Ross,
Supt. Welfare and Training.
Ottawa, July 8th, 1944.

H. F. Ruddy, Esq., Indian Agent, Golden Lake, Ontario.

Requests have been received from a few of the Agencies in Saskatchewan and Alberta for Male Shaver Goats, and I would appreciate hearing from you as to whether you will have any animals this year which would be suitable for shipment.

R. A. Hey,
Sys. Welfare and Training.
Ottawa, July 10, 1944.

Dear Mr. Morris:

The remarks in your Duck Lake report regarding sale goats for the Duck Lake and Blue Quills schools have been noted, but we are advised there are no sale goats available at Spanish this year; in fact, it appears the goats there were not bred this year due to Brother Crab being short of help and unable to devote sufficient time to the goats. However, we have written Mr. Ruddy at Golden Lake, requesting that none of the male goats there be castrated until it is known definitely whether or not some of these may be required for the above schools or any other locations in the West. Would you drop me a line regarding your views as to whether or not the Golden Lake goats would be satisfactory.

I have also written Inspector Schmidt asking him to make enquiries in British Columbia with a view to obtaining pure breed males for Duck Lake and Blue Quills. I might also state that Mr. Schmidt was instructed some time ago to purchase a sale Sennan in British Columbia for Grouard.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Sup't of Welfare & Training.

Mr. J. E. Morris,
c/o C. H. Simpson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
BALGARIE,
Saskatchewan.
The Pas, June 27th.

Dear Mr. Rose:

Regarding the sending of male goats to the Grouard, Blue Quill and Duck Lake schools as recommended in my reports I wish to make it clear that I never intended that young goats be sent. I do feel that good animals six months old could be sent without any difficulty. These three schools are very interested in the raising of goats to be distributed to needy T.B. Indians and we will have to encourage the project by helping to obtain breeding stock.

I investigated the possibility of obtaining Sasman male goats at Edmonton, Calgary and at any other place where I thought goats could be obtained. This question was very thoroughly discussed with Inspector Schmidt and all the agents I have visited today and in every case they state that there are no good breeding goats to be had. Mr. Schmidt stated regarding the purchase of goats in British Columbia that there are only a limited number available at a very high price and that in his opinion there has been a great deal of inbreeding already. He was of the opinion that if goats are to make a success of in the Agencies in the West good breeding stock will have to come from Ontario.

I would therefore suggest that Father Prinsen be asked to hold a number of good male goats until I return to Ottawa. I will provide him with shipping instructions so that the animals can be shipped, stopping over at certain points where the Farm Instructors can feed water and exercise them, so that they will reach their destination without hardship.

Yours truly,

(Sgt) J. E. Morris.
Battleford, Sask.,
July 17th, 1944.

Department of Mines & Resources, Indian Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Recently I transferred one milch goat from the Red Pheasant Indian Day School to the Blue Quill Indian Residential School, Saddle Lake Agency, as on account of the teacher leaving we had no responsible party to take charge of goat. At a later date it may be advisable to purchase a goat for Red Pheasant School.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.
528 Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Manitoba,
July 20th, 1944.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Re: 109-1-14 - Purchase of Goats for Duck Lake and Blue Quills Schools.

Acknowledging your letter of July 10th, I would recommend that young male goats be retained at Golden Lake for delivery to the above-mentioned schools some time this fall.

It is regretted that the pure bred herd at Spanish was not bred last year. If Brother Grubb is unable to devote sufficient time to look after this herd of goats it might be well to consider moving them to some other place. I might inform you that many of the Agents are very interested in the securing of goats to supply milk to Indians, and as there are very few pure bred herds in the West it will most likely be necessary to obtain goats in Ontario. It is therefore important that the herd at Spanish be bred this year and goats available for delivery next year.

Yours very truly,

J.E. Morris.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Superintendent of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
REPORT ON SADDLE LAKE INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1944.

Blue Quill's School;
Visited on June 10th. During the month Father LeTour received six goats, to be used in connection with schoolwork.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Mr. P. G. Lasenby,
Indian Agent,
NORWAY HOUSE, MANITOBA.

RE: GOATS.

You are authorized to buy sixteen female goats at fourteen dollars each ($14.00) and six male goats at ten dollars ($10.00) each from the Rev. Mr. Jones; payment to be made out of the Welfare Vote. You are also authorized to purchase two female goats and one male goat from Father Rivard at twenty-five dollars for the three animals.

This herd is to be established at Norway House; the milk to be used for tubercular patients and the children of families who are unable to provide milk.

There has been considerable inbreeding in this herd; therefore, you are requested to separate the males at the earliest possible date. Probably you can arrange to pasture them on another island until they are distributed. The male goat purchased from Father Rivard should be used with this herd.

One male goat has already been sent to Island Lake. The others should be disposed of as follows:

One to Father Trudell to establish a herd at Cross Lake.

One to Indian Agent Lovell at The Pas.

(Note: It is suggested that this goat be sent there by aeroplane when Dr. Rule next visits Norway House.)

Two good billies should be selected -

One to be sent to the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, Duck Lake, Saskatchewan.

One to the Blue Quill School in Alberta.

It is suggested that you write to Father Georges Letour, Duck Lake, Saskatchewan, and Father L.C. Letour, St. Paul, Alberta, asking them to provide you with the proper shipping instructions.

- Over -
NOTE: I understand they will not bring goats out on the "Keansors" until after the tourist season is over; therefore these two goats most likely will be shipped the later part of September or the first of October. In my opinion, it might be wise to send these goats via Prince Albert; the one for Duck Lake could be transported from there by truck, the one for the Blue Quill School could be placed off at a station on the main line to Edmonton. If this is done the goats will be delivered in the shortest possible time.

(Sgd) J. E. Morris.
Welfare and Training Division.
Ottawa, August 23, 1944.

Dear Mr. Morris:

Further to my letter of July 10th, regarding the shortage of male goats at Spanish, a letter has now been received from Father Prinsen in which he states they expect to have more kids than was originally anticipated.

I quote hereunder from Father Prinsen's letter:

"Following up your letter of March 30th (File 54-15) in reply to my letter of the 8th to Mr. Morris, I am pleased to say that we expect to have more kids than we thought there would be at that time. There are already five that have arrived, four billies and one nanny. There will be a good number of others I hope, as some of the nannies were bred than Brother Crab had thought. I shall let you know later this month as to the number of kids we expect to be able to provide this season."

In passing this information on as it has just occurred to me you may wish to alter the instructions you recently gave to Mr. Lesschey regarding the shipping of billies to Saskatchewan and Alberta.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Dept. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. J. E. Morris,
c/o S. H. Simpson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Saskatchewan.

REPORT ON SADDLE LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH SEPTEMBER, 1944.

Blue Quill's School

The return to school on Sept. 6th of the school children was very poor.

Father Letour had his milk cows inoculated against ? and it turned out very poor and infection setting in on the whole 20, he lost one of his pure bred cows. His herd was T.B. Teasted by Doctor Harold Spence of the Dominion Health of Animals Branch.

Doctor Bissonette of St. Paul was the veterinary that was responsible for the inoculation trouble. I visited the School on Sept. 12. I would have visited again on Sept. 29th but was away from the Agency.

W.P.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Blue Quills Ind. Res. School,
St. Paul, Alta.,
August 13, 1945.

Mr. J.E. Morris,
Welfare Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you that I taken delivery, last week, of the pure bred Saanen male goat shipped from Portage la Prairie, Man.

Reverend Father I. Geuthier, O.M.I., missionary at Beaver Lake Reserve, has asked me for the male goat that you sent to the School, from Norway House, last summer. They have three goats on the Reserve and the Indians seem to be interested in raising more. Would the Department allow me to send the goat in question?

Thanking you for your kind attention,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

L.C. Latour, O.M.I.
Rev. L.C. Latour, O.M.I.
Principal.
Ottawa, August 21, 1945.

Dear Father Latour—

I acknowledge your letter of August 13 advising that the pure bred Samson male goat shipped to you from Spanish has arrived safely. It is hoped that this animal will improve your goat herd.

Regarding your request that the male goat sent to you from Norway House last year be sent to the Beaver Lake Reserve as requested by Father L. Gauthier I wish to inform you that the goat may be sent there. It should be understood that after two years it should be moved to some other reserve. Every effort should be made to encourage Indians in the raising of goats so that a supply of milk will be available. Anything you can do in this respect would be very much appreciated.

Kindest regards to yourself,

Yours very truly,

J. E. Morris,
Welfare Division.

Reverend Father L. G. Latour, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Blue Quills Ind. Res. School,
St. Paul, Alberta.
Blue Quills Ind. Res. School,
St. Paul, Alta.,
August 28, 1945.

Mr. J.F. Morris,
Welfare Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you that the pure bred Saanen male goat recently received from Spanish, Ont., has died today.

On his arrival, the animal was very weak and very thin, and apparently had suffered of hunger. In spite of the good care that was given him, he could not recover, and this morning he suddenly grew worse and died in the afternoon.

For your information, I beg to add that I took delivery of same, immediately upon his arrival in St. Paul.

Yours very truly,

Rev. L.C. Letour, O.M.I.
Principal.
Ottawa, August 29th, 1945.

EX'D.

Dear Father Latour:

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter dated August 23rd reporting the death of the male goat recently received from Spanish, Ontario, and we are indeed very sorry to hear this.

Will you kindly advise at your early convenience whether you have, or can, arrange to obtain the services of a suitable animal for this season.

At the present moment there is no suitable animal available but if you have been unable to make satisfactory local arrangements an endeavour will be made to locate an animal for you. In the event you are able to make suitable arrangements for this Fall kindly advise whether or not you wish us to endeavour to locate a suitable animal for next Spring.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Reverend Father L.C. Latour, C.M.I.

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you, in answer to your letter of August 29th, that I will keep the male goat received last fall. I have been able to secure one for Rev. Father Gauthier, O.M.I., of Beaver Lake Reserve.

I would also appreciate your endeavour to locate a suitable animal for next Spring.

Thanking you sincerely,

Rev. L.C. Latour, O.M.I.
Principal.
Ottawa, September 18th, 1945.

Dear Father Letour:

I acknowledge your letter of September 12th, advising that you have made arrangements to retain a male goat for your herd; and should be pleased if a suitable animal could be located and shipped to you next Spring. Arrangements are being made to obtain another pure bred Saanen goat from the Spanish herd. This animal will be shipped next Spring - during the month of May or early in June - with a stop off at Portage la Prairie for a week or ten days and then sent forward to your School.

To have this animal delivered to you in the best possible condition and in the shortest time it is suggested that you accept delivery of him at Nipawin or Bemidji, and then taken to St. Paul either by car or truck, rather than have the animal sent all the way into Edmonton and back out to St. Paul.

I might inform you three goats were shipped from Portage la Prairie; one to Duck Lake; one to your School and one to the Youville School at Edmonton. It would appear that the two other goats arrived in good condition which would indicate that some neglect or delay was made at Edmonton in the shipment of the goat sent to your school.

If this suggestion regarding the shipment is agreeable please advise, indicating your approval.

Yours very truly,

J. E. Morris,
Welfare Division.

Reverend Father L.C. Letour, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Blue Quills Ind. Res. School,

I am today in receipt of a letter from the Reverend Father Latour, O.M.I., Principal of Blue Quills Ind. Residential School. The Father's letter reads as follows:

"I beg to advise you that the animal shipped by you arrived in St. Paul, by train, on Friday evening, July 26th and was taken to the school immediately. To my surprise, I found that it was a female goat instead of a male goat. Would you kindly let me know about the mistake."

The Goat that arrived here was a Nanny and was kept at the school for nearly a week. There could be no mistake made here as there are no other goats at the Portage School.

Mr. J.E. Morris,
Welfare Division,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I received from Portage la Prairie, on July 26th, the animal that had been shipped to the School, but to my surprise, I found that it was a female goat instead of a male goat. I immediately wrote to Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, on the next day, advising him about the mistake, but I have received no answer yet.

As I would need a male goat for this fall, I am writing to you in order that you may be able to secure me one before it is too late.

I am also awaiting instructions concerning the female goat now at school.

Yours very truly,

Rev. L.C. Latour, C.M.I.
Principal.
Dear Mr. Neary:

I have to thank you for your letter of the 9th current and regret that such a notable mistake was made by the young brother having charge of the goats. To assure you that the same mistake would be avoided by more personal supervision of the matter next time would be superfluous since the goat problem for us no longer, happily, exists.

May I have directions as to how we proceed in the matter of collecting for the goats which were sent by us to Golden Lake? Should we require a receipt from Indian agent Ruddy as to the number of goats received from us and then work on the price offered by the Department?

If it is not too late may we offer you all good wishes of success in this work, and invite you to visit us whenever the occasion may offer?

Yours sincerely,

(Rev.) J.R. Oliver, S.J.
Principal.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,

June 27, 1950.

Col. Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

This will advise that I have been approached with a request for assistance towards an improvement of a dairy herd at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School. The dairy herd at this school is not an asset in this line as they are more of a beef variety. The Reverend Principal is prepared to sell the milking class in this herd with a view of obtaining ten or twelve head of good milk stock. The proceeds for the sale of this stock will by no means cover the cost of the good milk strain required and the request was therefore being made to assist in covering the balance required.

It is felt that approximately $3000.00 will be required to make the total purchase. Of this, $1,000.00 will be covered from the sale of the present stock and the Reverend Principal is prepared to put up $1,000.00, which leaves a balance of $1,000.00. I advised Father Hollande, principal of the school, that I was not aware of this information but felt if any assistance was granted that it would have to be covered in estimates.

May I please be advised what action should be taken in this regards. It is my opinion that a better class of dairy cattle would be obtained with the least possible delay and any information or assistance will be greatly appreciated. There is a dairy breeders meeting being held in St. Paul on July 15, 1950 and an answer to this letter by that time would give us fact on which to make further inquiries.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

WKT/pdh
June 30th, 1950.

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alberta.

Re: Blue Quills Residential School
Your File 118-6-7

We have your letter of the 27th instant with reference to the request received from the Principal of the above school for an amount of $1,000.00 to assist him in buying cattle.

It is not the general policy of the Department to provide cattle at a residential school except when the school is first opened. When the Blue Quills Residential School was opened in 1932, a number of milking cows were purchased by the Department.

In view of our present policy, I regret that favourable consideration cannot be given to the Principal's request.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Del Carter requisites
Blue Quills Indian Residential School,
Sacred Heart, P.O., Alta., Jan. 29th, 1931.

Honourable Sir:

With regards the requisition for the farm, I have asked for six working horses; at present there are here five horses, of which two are 18 years old. As to milking cows, I have applied for 10; the 10 cows here at the present are also getting old and soon will have to be slaughtered for beef.

You will notice that there is also a list for the shop, mostly of tools required for repairs to house or of farm equipment; and this will prove a great economy to the institution as our engineer can thereby attend to any urgent and necessary repairs.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. Jos. Angin.
Principal.
